Parsing [sent. 1 len. 139]: Oliver Twist or The Parish Boy 's Progress by Charles Dickens CHAPTER I TREATS OF THE PLACE WHERE OLIVER TWIST WAS BORN AND OF THE CIRCUMSTANCES ATTENDING HIS BIRTH Among other public buildings in a certain town , which for many reasons it will be prudent to refrain from mentioning , and to which I will assign no fictitious name , there is one anciently common to most towns , great or small : to wit , a workhouse ; and in this workhouse was born ; on a day and date which I need not trouble myself to repeat , inasmuch as it can be of no possible consequence to the reader , in this stage of the business at all events ; the item of mortality whose name is prefixed to the head of this chapter .

Parsing [sent. 46 len. 21]: The hungry and destitute situation of the infant orphan was duly reported by the workhouse authorities to the parish authorities .
Parsing [sent. 47 len. 45]: The parish authorities inquired with dignity of the workhouse authorities , whether there was no female then domiciled in ` the house ' who was in a situation to impart to Oliver Twist , the consolation and nourishment of which he stood in need .
Parsing [sent. 48 len. 12]: The workhouse authorities replied with humility , that there was not .
Parsing [sent. 49 len. 94]: Upon this , the parish authorities magnanimously and humanely resolved , that Oliver should be ` farmed , ' or , in other words , that he should be dispatched to a branch-workhouse some three miles off , where twenty or thirty other juvenile offenders against the poor-laws , rolled about the floor all day , without the inconvenience of too much food or too much clothing , under the parental superintendence of an elderly female , who received the culprits at and for the consideration of sevenpence-halfpenny per small head per week .
Parsing [sent. 50 len. 35]: Sevenpence-halfpenny 's worth per week is a good round diet for a child ; a great deal may be got for sevenpence-halfpenny , quite enough to overload its stomach , and make it uncomfortable .
Parsing [sent. 51 len. 33]: The elderly female was a woman of wisdom and experience ; she knew what was good for children ; and she had a very accurate perception of what was good for herself .
Parsing [sent. 52 len. 34]: So , she appropriated the greater part of the weekly stipend to her own use , and consigned the rising parochial generation to even a shorter allowance than was originally provided for them .
Parsing [sent. 53 len. 19]: Thereby finding in the lowest depth a deeper still ; and proving herself a very great experimental philosopher .
Parsing [sent. 54 len. 82]: Everybody knows the story of another experimental philosopher who had a great theory about a horse being able to live without eating , and who demonstrated it so well , that he had got his own horse down to a straw a day , and would unquestionably have rendered him a very spirited and rampacious animal on nothing at all , if he had not died , four-and-twenty hours before he was to have had his first comfortable bait of air .
Parsing [sent. 55 len. 121]: Unfortunately for , the experimenal philosophy of the female to whose protecting care Oliver Twist was delivered over , a similar result usually attended the operation of HER system ; for at the very moment when the child had contrived to exist upon the smallest possible portion of the weakest possible food , it did perversely happen in eight and a half cases out of ten , either that it sickened from want and cold , or fell into the fire from neglect , or got half-smothered by accident ; in any one of which cases , the miserable little being was usually summoned into another world , and there gathered to the fathers it had never known in this .
Parsing [sent. 56 len. 84]: Occasionally , when there was some more than usually interesting inquest upon a parish child who had been overlooked in turning up a bedstead , or inadvertently scalded to death when there happened to be a washing -- though the latter accident was very scarce , anything approaching to a washing being of rare occurance in the farm -- the jury would take it into their heads to ask troublesome questions , or the parishioners would rebelliously affix their signatures to a remonstrance .

Parsing [sent. 194 len. 51]: And this was it : The members of this board were very sage , deep , philosophical men ; and when they came to turn their attention to the workhouse , they found out at once , what ordinary folks would nver have discovered -- the poor people liked it !
Parsing [sent. 195 len. 52]: It was a regular place of public entertainment for the poorer classes ; a tavern where there was nothing to pay ; a public breakfast , dinner , tea , and supper all the year round ; a brick and mortar elysium , where it was all play and no work .

Parsing [sent. 199 len. 54]: With this view , they contracted with the water-works to lay on an unlimited supply of water ; and with a corn-factor to supply periodically small quantities of oatmeal ; and issued three meals of thin gruel a day , with an onion twice a week , and half a roll of Sundays .
Parsing [sent. 200 len. 78]: They made a great many other wise and humane regulations , having reference to the ladies , which it is not necessary to repeat ; kindly undertook to divorce poor married people , in consequence of the great expense of a suit in Doctors ' Commons ; and , instead of compelling a man to support his family , as they had theretofore done , took his family away from him , and made him a bachelor !
Parsing [sent. 201 len. 50]: There is no saying how many applicants for relief , under these last two heads , might have started up in all classes of society , if it had not been coupled with the workhouse ; but the board were long-headed men , and had provided for this difficulty .
Parsing [sent. 202 len. 16]: The relief was inseparable from the workhouse and the gruel ; and that frightened people .
Parsing [sent. 203 len. 18]: For the first six months after Oliver Twist was removed , the system was in full operation .
Parsing [sent. 204 len. 49]: It was rather expensive at first , in consequence of the increase in the undertaker 's bill , and the necessity of taking in the clothes of all the paupers , which fluttered loosely on their wasted , shrunken forms , after a week or two 's gruel .
Parsing [sent. 205 len. 21]: But the number of workhouse inmates got thin as well as the paupers ; and the board were in ecstasies .
Parsing [sent. 206 len. 50]: The room in which the boys were fed , was a large stone hall , with a copper at one end : out of which the master , dressed in an apron for the purpose , and assisted by one or two women , ladled the gruel at mealtimes .
Parsing [sent. 207 len. 34]: Of this festive composition each boy had one porringer , and no more -- except on occasions of great public rejoicing , when he had two ounces and a quarter of bread besides .
Parsing [sent. 208 len. 6]: The bowls never wanted washing .
Parsing [sent. 209 len. 95]: The boys polished them with their spoons till they shone again ; and when they had performed this operation -LRB- which never took very long , the spoons being nearly as large as the bowls -RRB- , they would sit staring at the copper , with such eager eyes , as if they could have devoured the very bricks of which it was composed ; employing themselves , meanwhile , in sucking their fingers most assiduously , with the view of catching up any stray splashes of gruel that might have been cast thereon .
Parsing [sent. 210 len. 6]: Boys have generally excellent appetites .
Parsing [sent. 211 len. 103]: Oliver Twist and his companions suffered the tortures of slow starvation for three months : at last they got so voracious and wild with hunger , that one boy , who was tall for his age , and had n't been used to that sort of thing -LRB- for his father had kept a small cook-shop -RRB- , hinted darkly to his companions , that unless he had another basin of gruel per diem , he was afraid he might some night happen to eat the boy who slept next him , who happened to be a weakly youth of tender age .
Parsing [sent. 212 len. 14]: He had a wild , hungry eye ; and they implicitly believed him .
Parsing [sent. 213 len. 32]: A council was held ; lots were cast who should walk up to the master after supper that evening , and ask for more ; and it fell to Oliver Twist .
Parsing [sent. 214 len. 10]: The evening arrived ; the boys took their places .
Parsing [sent. 215 len. 40]: The master , in his cook 's uniform , stationed himself at the copper ; his pauper assistants ranged themselves behind him ; the gruel was served out ; and a long grace was said over the short commons .
Parsing [sent. 216 len. 22]: The gruel disappeared ; the boys whispered each other , and winked at Oliver ; while his next neighbours nudged him .
Parsing [sent. 217 len. 16]: Child as he was , he was desperate with hunger , and reckless with misery .
Parsing [sent. 218 len. 38]: He rose from the table ; and advancing to the master , basin and spoon in hand , said : somewhat alarmed at his own temerity : ` Please , sir , I want some more . '
Parsing [sent. 219 len. 15]: The master was a fat , healthy man ; but he turned very pale .
Parsing [sent. 220 len. 22]: He gazed in stupified astonishment on the small rebel for some seconds , and then clung for support to the copper .
Parsing [sent. 221 len. 12]: The assistants were paralysed with wonder ; the boys with fear .
Parsing [sent. 222 len. 4]: ` What ! '
Parsing [sent. 223 len. 11]: said the master at length , in a faint voice .
Parsing [sent. 224 len. 16]: ` Please , sir , ' replied Oliver , ' I want some more . '
Parsing [sent. 225 len. 26]: The master aimed a blow at Oliver 's head with the ladle ; pinioned him in his arm ; and shrieked aloud for the beadle .
Parsing [sent. 226 len. 41]: The board were sitting in solemn conclave , when Mr. Bumble rushed into the room in great excitement , and addressing the gentleman in the high chair , said , ` Mr. Limbkins , I beg your pardon , sir !
Parsing [sent. 227 len. 8]: Oliver Twist has asked for more ! '
Parsing [sent. 228 len. 6]: There was a general start .
Parsing [sent. 229 len. 7]: Horror was depicted on every countenance .
Parsing [sent. 230 len. 5]: ` For MORE ! '
Parsing [sent. 231 len. 4]: said Mr. Limbkins .
Parsing [sent. 232 len. 11]: ` Compose yourself , Bumble , and answer me distinctly .
Parsing [sent. 233 len. 21]: Do I understand that he asked for more , after he had eaten the supper allotted by the dietary ? '
Parsing [sent. 234 len. 10]: ` He did , sir , ' replied Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 235 len. 17]: ` That boy will be hung , ' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat . '
Parsing [sent. 236 len. 9]: I know that boy will be hung . '
Parsing [sent. 237 len. 8]: Nobody controverted the prophetic gentleman 's opinion .
Parsing [sent. 238 len. 6]: An animated discussion took place .
Parsing [sent. 239 len. 41]: Oliver was ordered into instant confinement ; and a bill was next morning pasted on the outside of the gate , offering a reward of five pounds to anybody who would take Oliver Twist off the hands of the parish .
Parsing [sent. 240 len. 30]: In other words , five pounds and Oliver Twist were offered to any man or woman who wanted an apprentice to any trade , business , or calling . '
Parsing [sent. 241 len. 58]: I never was more convinced of anything in my life , ' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat , as he knocked at the gate and read the bill next morning : ' I never was more convinced of anything in my life , than I am that that boy will come to be hung . '
Parsing [sent. 242 len. 58]: As I purpose to show in the sequel whether the white waistcoated gentleman was right or not , I should perhaps mar the interest of this narrative -LRB- supposing it to possess any at all -RRB- , if I ventured to hint just yet , whether the life of Oliver Twist had this violent termination or no .
Parsing [sent. 243 len. 62]: CHAPTER III RELATES HOW OLIVER TWIST WAS VERY NEAR GETTING A PLACE WHICH WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN A SINECURE For a week after the commission of the impious and profane offence of asking for more , Oliver remained a close prisoner in the dark and solitary room to which he had been consigned by the wisdom and mercy of the board .
Parsing [sent. 244 len. 70]: It appears , at first sight not unreasonable to suppose , that , if he had entertained a becoming feeling of respect for the prediction of the gentleman in the white waistcoat , he would have established that sage individual 's prophetic character , once and for ever , by tying one end of his pocket-handkerchief to a hook in the wall , and attaching himself to the other .
Parsing [sent. 245 len. 62]: To the performance of this feat , however , there was one obstacle : namely , that pocket-handkerchiefs being decided articles of luxury , had been , for all future times and ages , removed from the noses of paupers by the express order of the board , in council assembled : solemnly given and pronounced under their hands and seals .
Parsing [sent. 246 len. 13]: There was a still greater obstacle in Oliver 's youth and childishness .
Parsing [sent. 247 len. 82]: He only cried bitterly all day ; and , when the long , dismal night came on , spread his little hands before his eyes to shut out the darkness , and crouching in the corner , tried to sleep : ever and anon waking with a start and tremble , and drawing himself closer and closer to the wall , as if to feel even its cold hard surface were a protection in the gloom and loneliness which surrounded him .
Parsing [sent. 248 len. 44]: Let it not be supposed by the enemies of ` the system , ' that , during the period of his solitary incarceration , Oliver was denied the benefit of exercise , the pleasure of society , or the advantages of religious consolation .
Parsing [sent. 249 len. 59]: As for exercise , it was nice cold weather , and he was allowed to perform his ablutions every morning under the pump , in a stone yard , in the presence of Mr. Bumble , who prevented his catching cold , and caused a tingling sensation to pervade his frame , by repeated applications of the cane .
Parsing [sent. 250 len. 29]: As for society , he was carried every other day into the hall where the boys dined , and there sociably flogged as a public warning and example .
Parsing [sent. 251 len. 119]: And so for from being denied the advantages of religious consolation , he was kicked into the same apartment every evening at prayer-time , and there permitted to listen to , and console his mind with , a general supplication of the boys , containing a special clause , therein inserted by authority of the board , in which they entreated to be made good , virtuous , contented , and obedient , and to be guarded from the sins and vices of Oliver Twist : whom the supplication distinctly set forth to be under the exclusive patronage and protection of the powers of wickedness , and an article direct from the manufactory of the very Devil himself .
Parsing [sent. 252 len. 56]: It chanced one morning , while Oliver 's affairs were in this auspicious and confortable state , that Mr. Gamfield , chimney-sweep , went his way down the High Street , deeply cogitating in his mind his ways and means of paying certain arrears of rent , for which his landlord had become rather pressing .
Parsing [sent. 253 len. 55]: Mr. Gamfield 's most sanguine estimate of his finances could not raise them within full five pounds of the desired amount ; and , in a species of arthimetical desperation , he was alternately cudgelling his brains and his donkey , when passing the workhouse , his eyes encountered the bill on the gate .
Parsing [sent. 254 len. 6]: ` Wo -- o ! '
Parsing [sent. 255 len. 7]: said Mr. Gamfield to the donkey .
Parsing [sent. 256 len. 57]: The donkey was in a state of profound abstraction : wondering , probably , whether he was destined to be regaled with a cabbage-stalk or two when he had disposed of the two sacks of soot with which the little cart was laden ; so , without noticing the word of command , he jogged onward .
Parsing [sent. 257 len. 44]: Mr. Gamfield growled a fierce imprecation on the donkey generally , but more particularly on his eyes ; and , running after him , bestowed a blow on his head , which would inevitably have beaten in any skull but a donkey 's .
Parsing [sent. 258 len. 37]: Then , catching hold of the bridle , he gave his jaw a sharp wrench , by way of gentle reminder that he was not his own master ; and by these means turned him round .
Parsing [sent. 259 len. 20]: He then gave him another blow on the head , just to stun him till he came back again .
Parsing [sent. 260 len. 17]: Having completed these arrangements , he walked up to the gate , to read the bill .
Parsing [sent. 261 len. 29]: The gentleman with the white waistcoat was standing at the gate with his hands behind him , after having delivered himself of some profound sentiments in the board-room .
Parsing [sent. 262 len. 43]: Having witnessed the little dispute between Mr. Gamfield and the donkey , he smiled joyously when that person came up to read the bill , for he saw at once that Mr. Gamfield was exactly the sort of master Oliver Twist wanted .
Parsing [sent. 263 len. 67]: Mr. Gamfield smiled , too , as he perused the document ; for five pounds was just the sum he had been wishing for ; and , as to the boy with which it was encumbered , Mr. Gamfield , knowing what the dietary of the workhouse was , well knew he would be a nice small pattern , just the very thing for register stoves .
Parsing [sent. 264 len. 34]: So , he spelt the bill through again , from beginning to end ; and then , touching his fur cap in token of humility , accosted the gentleman in the white waistcoat .
Parsing [sent. 265 len. 20]: ` This here boy , sir , wot the parish wants to ` prentis , ' said Mr. Gamfield .
Parsing [sent. 266 len. 20]: ` Ay , my man , ' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat , with a condescending smile .
Parsing [sent. 267 len. 6]: ` What of him ? '
Parsing [sent. 268 len. 44]: ` If the parish vould like him to learn a right pleasant trade , in a good ` spectable chimbley-sweepin ' bisness , ' said Mr. Gamfield , ' I wants a ` prentis , and I am ready to take him . '
Parsing [sent. 269 len. 13]: ` Walk in , ' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat .
Parsing [sent. 270 len. 51]: Mr. Gamfield having lingered behind , to give the donkey another blow on the head , and another wrench of the jaw , as a caution not to run away in his absence , followed the gentleman with the white waistcoat into the room where Oliver had first seen him .
Parsing [sent. 271 len. 20]: ` It 's a nasty trade , ' said Mr. Limbkins , when Gamfield had again stated his wish .
Parsing [sent. 272 len. 16]: ` Young boys have been smothered in chimneys before now , ' said another gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 273 len. 68]: ` That 's acause they damped the straw afore they lit it in the chimbley to make 'em come down again , ' said Gamfield ; ` that 's all smoke , and no blaze ; vereas smoke ai n't o ' no use at all in making a boy come down , for it only sinds him to sleep , and that 's wot he likes .
Parsing [sent. 274 len. 31]: Boys is wery obstinit , and wery lazy , Gen ` l'men , and there 's nothink like a good hot blaze to make 'em come down vith a run .
Parsing [sent. 275 len. 31]: It 's humane too , gen ` l'men , acause , even if they 've stuck in the chimbley , roasting their feet makes 'em struggle to hextricate theirselves . '
Parsing [sent. 276 len. 27]: The gentleman in the white waistcoat appeared very much amused by this explanation ; but his mirth was speedily checked by a look from Mr. Limbkins .
Parsing [sent. 277 len. 49]: The board then procedded to converse among themselves for a few minutes , but in so low a tone , that the words ` saving of expenditure , ' ` looked well in the accounts , ' ` have a printed report published , ' were alone audible .
Parsing [sent. 278 len. 21]: These only chanced to be heard , indeed , or account of their being very frequently repeated with great emphasis .
Parsing [sent. 279 len. 41]: At length the whispering ceased ; and the members of the board , having resumed their seats and their solemnity , Mr. Limbkins said : ` We have considered your proposition , and we do n't approve of it . '
Parsing [sent. 280 len. 14]: ` Not at all , ' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat .
Parsing [sent. 281 len. 10]: ` Decidedly not , ' added the other members .
Parsing [sent. 282 len. 53]: As Mr. Gamfield did happen to labour under the slight imputation of having bruised three or four boys to death already , it occurred to him that the board had , perhaps , in some unaccountable freak , taken it into their heads that this extraneous circumstance ought to influence their proceedings .
Parsing [sent. 283 len. 44]: It was very unlike their general mode of doing business , if they had ; but still , as he had no particular wish to revive the rumour , he twisted his cap in his hands , and walked slowly from the table .
Parsing [sent. 284 len. 15]: ` So you wo n't let me have him , gen ` l'men ? '
Parsing [sent. 285 len. 9]: said Mr. Gamfield , pausing near the door .

Parsing [sent. 287 len. 32]: Mr. Gamfield 's countenance brightened , as , with a quick step , he returned to the table , and said , ` What 'll you give , gen ` l'men ?

Parsing [sent. 315 len. 5]: The bargain was made .
Parsing [sent. 316 len. 30]: Mr. Bumble , was at once instructed that Oliver Twist and his indentures were to be conveyed before the magistrate , for signature and approval , that very afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 317 len. 29]: In pursuance of this determination , little Oliver , to his excessive astonishment , was released from bondage , and ordered to put himself into a clean shirt .
Parsing [sent. 318 len. 39]: He had hardly achieved this very unusual gymnastic performance , when Mr. Bumble brought him , with his own hands , a basin of gruel , and the holiday allowance of two ounces and a quarter of bread .
Parsing [sent. 319 len. 45]: At this tremendous sight , Oliver began to cry very piteously : thinking , not unaturally , that the board must have determined to kill him for some useful purpose , or they never would have begun to fatten him up in that way .
Parsing [sent. 320 len. 30]: ` Do n't make your eyes red , Oliver , but eat your food and be thankful , ' said Mr. Bumble , in a tone of impressive pomposity .
Parsing [sent. 321 len. 17]: ` You 're a going to be made a ` prentice of , Oliver . ' '
Parsing [sent. 322 len. 6]: A prentice , sir ! '
Parsing [sent. 323 len. 6]: said the child , trembling .
Parsing [sent. 324 len. 10]: ` Yes , Oliver , ' said Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 325 len. 58]: ` The kind and blessed gentleman which is so amny parents to you , Oliver , when you have none of your own : are a going to ` prentice you : and to set you up in life , and make a man of you : although the expense to the parish is three pound ten !
Parsing [sent. 326 len. 7]: -- three pound ten , Oliver !
Parsing [sent. 327 len. 10]: -- seventy shillins -- one hundred and forty sixpences !
Parsing [sent. 328 len. 14]: -- and all for a naughty orphan which noboday ca n't love . '
Parsing [sent. 329 len. 32]: As Mr. Bumble paused to take breath , after delivering this address in an awful voice , the tears rolled down the poor child 's face , and he sobbed bitterly .
Parsing [sent. 330 len. 33]: ` Come , ' said Mr. Bumble , somewhat less pompously , for it was gratifying to his feelings to observe the effect his eloquence had produced ; ` Come , Oliver !
Parsing [sent. 331 len. 28]: Wipe your eyes with the cuffs of your jacket , and do n't cry into your gruel ; that 's a very foolish action , Oliver . '
Parsing [sent. 332 len. 14]: It certainly was , for there was quite enough water in it already .
Parsing [sent. 333 len. 89]: On their way to the magistrate , Mr. Bumble instructed Oliver that all he would have to do , would be to look very happy , and say , when the gentleman asked him if he wanted to be apprenticed , that he should like it very much indeed ; both of which injunctions Oliver promised to obey : the rather as Mr. Bumble threw in a gentle hint , that if he failed in either particular , there was no telling what would be done to him .
Parsing [sent. 334 len. 35]: When they arrived at the office , he was shut up in a little room by himself , and admonished by Mr. Bumble to stay there , until he came back to fetch him .
Parsing [sent. 335 len. 15]: There the boy remained , with a palpitating heart , for half an hour .
Parsing [sent. 336 len. 37]: At the expiration of which time Mr. Bumble thrust in his head , unadorned with the cocked hat , and said aloud : ` Now , Oliver , my dear , come to the gentleman . '
Parsing [sent. 337 len. 35]: As Mr. Bumble said this , he put on a grim and threatening look , and added , in a low voice , ` Mind what I told you , you young rascal ! '
Parsing [sent. 338 len. 43]: Oliver stared innocently in Mr. Bumble 's face at this somewhat contradictory style of address ; but that gentleman prevented his offering any remark thereupon , by leading him at once into an adjoining room : the door of which was open .
Parsing [sent. 339 len. 11]: It was a large room , with a great window .
Parsing [sent. 340 len. 46]: Behind a desk , sat two old gentleman with powdered heads : one of whom was reading the newspaper ; while the other was perusing , with the aid of a pair of tortoise-shell spectacles , a small piece of parchment which lay before him .
Parsing [sent. 341 len. 41]: Mr. Limbkins was standing in front of the desk on one side ; and Mr. Gamfield , with a partially washed face , on the other ; while two or three bluff-looking men , in top-boots , were lounging about .
Parsing [sent. 342 len. 38]: The old gentleman with the spectacles gradually dozed off , over the little bit of parchment ; and there was a short pause , after Oliver had been stationed by Mr. Bumble in front of the desk .
Parsing [sent. 343 len. 14]: ` This is the boy , your worship , ' said Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 344 len. 34]: The old gentleman who was reading the newspaper raised his head for a moment , and pulled the other old gentleman by the sleeve ; whereupon , the last-mentioned old gentleman woke up .
Parsing [sent. 345 len. 9]: ` Oh , is this the boy ? '
Parsing [sent. 346 len. 5]: said the old gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 347 len. 12]: ` This is him , sir , ' replied Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 348 len. 10]: ` Bow to the magistrate , my dear . '
Parsing [sent. 349 len. 10]: Oliver roused himself , and made his best obeisance .
Parsing [sent. 350 len. 37]: He had been wondering , with his eyes fixed on the magistrates ' powder , whether all boards were born with that white stuff on their heads , and were boards from thenceforth on that account .
Parsing [sent. 351 len. 19]: ` Well , ' said the old gentleman , ' I suppose he 's fond of chimney-sweeping ? '
Parsing [sent. 352 len. 31]: ` He doats on it , your worship , ' replied Bumble ; giving Oliver a sly pinch , to intimate that he had better not say he did n't .
Parsing [sent. 353 len. 12]: ` And he WILL be a sweep , will he ? '
Parsing [sent. 354 len. 5]: inquired the old gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 355 len. 26]: ` If we was to bind him to any other trade to-morrow , he 'd run away simultaneous , your worship , ' replied Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 356 len. 37]: ` And this man that 's to be his master -- you , sir -- you 'll treat him well , and feed him , and do all that sort of thing , will you ? '
Parsing [sent. 357 len. 5]: said the old gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 358 len. 18]: ` When I says I will , I means I will , ' replied Mr. Gamfield doggedly .
Parsing [sent. 359 len. 50]: ` You 're a rough speaker , my friend , but you look an honest , open-hearted man , ' said the old gentleman : turning his spectacles in the direction of the candidate for Oliver 's premium , whose villainous countenance was a regular stamped receipt for cruelty .
Parsing [sent. 360 len. 25]: But the magistrate was half blind and half childish , so he could n't reasonably be expected to discern what other people did . '
Parsing [sent. 361 len. 18]: I hope I am , sir , ' said Mr. Gamfield , with an ugly leer . '
Parsing [sent. 362 len. 33]: I have no doubt you are , my friend , ' replied the old gentleman : fixing his spectacles more firmly on his nose , and looking about him for the inkstand .
Parsing [sent. 363 len. 10]: It was the critical moment of Oliver 's fate .
Parsing [sent. 364 len. 36]: If the inkstand had been where the old gentleman though it was , he would have dipped his pen into it , and signed the indentures , and Oliver would have been straightway hurried off .
Parsing [sent. 365 len. 104]: But , as it chanced to be immediately under his nose , it followed , as a matter of course , that he looked all over his desk for it , without finding it ; and happening in the course of his search to look straight before him , his gaze encountered the pale and terrified face of Oliver Twist : who , despite all the admonitory looks and pinches of Bumble , was regarding the repulsive countenance of his future master , with a mingled expression of horror and fear , too palpable to be mistaken , even by a half-blind magistrate .
Parsing [sent. 366 len. 30]: The old gentleman stopped , laid down his pen , and looked from Oliver to Mr. Limbkins ; who attempted to take snuff with a cheerful and unconcerned aspect .
Parsing [sent. 367 len. 5]: ` My boy ! '
Parsing [sent. 368 len. 12]: said the old gentleman , ` you look pale and alarmed .
Parsing [sent. 369 len. 6]: What is the matter ? '
Parsing [sent. 370 len. 30]: ` Stand a little away from him , Beadle , ' said the other magistrate : laying aside the paper , and leaning forward with an expression of interest .
Parsing [sent. 371 len. 18]: ` Now , boy , tell us what 's the matter : do n't be afraid . '
Parsing [sent. 372 len. 49]: Oliver fell on his knees , and clasping his hands together , prayed that they would order him back to the dark room -- that they would starve him -- beat him -- kill him if they pleased -- rather than send him away with that dreadful man .
Parsing [sent. 373 len. 4]: ` Well ! '
Parsing [sent. 374 len. 14]: said Mr. Bumble , raising his hands and eyes with most impressive solemnite .
Parsing [sent. 375 len. 3]: ` Well !

Parsing [sent. 382 len. 7]: Mr. Bumble was stupefied with astonishment .
Parsing [sent. 383 len. 8]: A beadle ordered to hold his tongue !
Parsing [sent. 384 len. 4]: A moral revolution !
Parsing [sent. 385 len. 16]: The old gentleman in the tortoise-shell spectacles looked at his companion , he nodded significantly .
Parsing [sent. 386 len. 25]: ` We refuse to sanction these indentures , ' said the old gentleman : tossing aside the piece of parchment as he spoke . '

Parsing [sent. 388 len. 23]: ` The magistrates are not called upon to pronounce any opinion on the matter , ' said the second old gentleman sharply .
Parsing [sent. 389 len. 14]: ` Take the boy back to the workhouse , and treat him kindly .
Parsing [sent. 390 len. 7]: He seems to want it . '
Parsing [sent. 391 len. 36]: That same evening , the gentleman in the white waistcoat most positively and decidedly affirmed , not only that Oliver would be hung , but that he would be drawn and quartered into the bargain .
Parsing [sent. 392 len. 57]: Mr. Bumble shook his head with gloomy mystery , and said he wished he might come to good ; whereunto Mr. Gamfield replied , that he wished he might come to him ; which , although he agreed with the beadle in most matters , would seem to be a wish of a totaly opposite description .
Parsing [sent. 393 len. 33]: The next morning , the public were once informed that Oliver Twist was again To Let , and that five pounds would be paid to anybody who would take possession of him .
Parsing [sent. 394 len. 61]: CHAPTER IV OLIVER , BEING OFFERED ANOTHER PLACE , MAKES HIS FIRST ENTRY INTO PUBLIC LIFE In great families , when an advantageous place can not be obtained , either in possession , reversion , remainder , or expectancy , for the young man who is growing up , it is a very general custom to send him to sea .
Parsing [sent. 395 len. 37]: The board , in imitation of so wise and salutary an example , took counsel together on the expediency of shipping off Oliver Twist , in some small trading vessel bound to a good unhealthy port .
Parsing [sent. 396 len. 71]: This suggested itself as the very best thing that could possibly be done with him : the probability being , that the skipper would flog him to death , in a playful mood , some day after dinner , or would knock his brains out with an iron bar ; both pastimes being , as is pretty generally known , very favourite and common recreations among gentleman of that class .
Parsing [sent. 397 len. 52]: The more the case presented itself to the board , in this point of view , the more manifold the advantages of the step appeared ; so , they came to the conclusion that the only way of providing for Oliver effectually , was to send him to sea without delay .
Parsing [sent. 398 len. 62]: Mr. Bumble had been despatched to make various preliminary inquiries , with the view of finding out some captain or other who wanted a cabin-boy without any friends ; and was returning to the workhouse to communicate the result of his mission ; when he encountered at the gate , no less a person than Mr. Sowerberry , the parochial undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 399 len. 32]: Mr. Sowerberry was a tall gaunt , large-jointed man , attired in a suit of threadbare black , with darned cotton stockings of the same colour , and shoes to answer .
Parsing [sent. 400 len. 23]: His features were not naturally intended to wear a smiling aspect , but he was in general rather given to professional jocosity .
Parsing [sent. 401 len. 28]: His step was elastic , and his face betokened inward pleasantry , as he advanced to Mr. Bumble , and shook him cordially by the hand . '
Parsing [sent. 402 len. 22]: I have taken the measure of the two women that died last night , Mr. Bumble , ' said the undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 403 len. 42]: ` You 'll make your fortune , Mr. Sowerberry , ' said the beadle , as he thrust his thumb and forefinger into the proferred snuff-box of the undertaker : which was an ingenious little model of a patent coffin . '
Parsing [sent. 404 len. 32]: I say you 'll make your fortune , Mr. Sowerberry , ' repeated Mr. Bumble , tapping the undertaker on the shoulder , in a friendly manner , with his cane .
Parsing [sent. 405 len. 5]: ` Think so ? '
Parsing [sent. 406 len. 18]: said the undertaker in a tone which half admitted and half disputed the probability of the event .
Parsing [sent. 407 len. 15]: ` The prices allowed by the board are very small , Mr. Bumble . '
Parsing [sent. 408 len. 29]: ` So are the coffins , ' replied the beadle : with precisely as near an approach to a laugh as a great official ought to indulge in .
Parsing [sent. 409 len. 24]: Mr. Sowerberry was much tickled at this : as of course he ought to be ; and laughed a long time without cessation .
Parsing [sent. 410 len. 55]: ` Well , well , Mr. Bumble , ' he said at length , ` there 's no denying that , since the new system of feeding has come in , the coffins are something narrower and more shallow than they used to be ; but we must have some profit , Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 411 len. 23]: Well-seasoned timber is an expensive article , sir ; and all the iron handles come , by canal , from Birmingham . '
Parsing [sent. 412 len. 17]: ` Well , well , ' said Mr. Bumble , ` every trade has its drawbacks .
Parsing [sent. 413 len. 11]: A fair profit is , of course , allowable . '
Parsing [sent. 414 len. 43]: ` Of course , of course , ' replied the undertaker ; ` and if I do n't get a profit upon this or that particular article , why , I make it up in the long-run , you see -- he !
Parsing [sent. 415 len. 2]: he !
Parsing [sent. 416 len. 3]: he ! '
Parsing [sent. 417 len. 9]: ` Just so , ' said Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 418 len. 55]: ` Though I must say , ' continued the undertaker , resuming the current of observations which the beadle had interrupted : ` though I must say , Mr. Bumble , that I have to contend against one very great disadvantage : which is , that all the stout people go off the quickest .
Parsing [sent. 419 len. 68]: The people who have been better off , and have paid rates for many years , are the first to sink when they come into the house ; and let me tell you , Mr. Bumble , that three or four inches over one 's calculation makes a great hole in one 's profits : especially when one has a family to provide for , sir . '
Parsing [sent. 420 len. 46]: As Mr. Sowerberry said this , with the becoming indignation of an ill-used man ; and as Mr. Bumble felt that it rather tended to convey a reflection on the honour of the parish ; the latter gentleman thought it advisable to change the subject .
Parsing [sent. 421 len. 14]: Oliver Twist being uppermost in his mind , he made him his theme .
Parsing [sent. 422 len. 24]: ` By the bye , ' said Mr. Bumble , ` you do n't know anybody who wants a boy , do you ?
Parsing [sent. 423 len. 25]: A porochial ` prentis , who is at present a dead-weight ; a millstone , as I may say , round the porochial throat ?
Parsing [sent. 424 len. 10]: Liberal terms , Mr. Sowerberry , liberal terms ? '
Parsing [sent. 425 len. 39]: As Mr. Bumble spoke , he raised his cane to the bill above him , and gave three distinct raps upon the words ` five pounds ' : which were printed thereon in Roman capitals of gigantic size .
Parsing [sent. 426 len. 4]: ` Gadso ! '
Parsing [sent. 427 len. 31]: said the undertaker : taking Mr. Bumble by the gilt-edged lappel of his official coat ; ` that 's just the very thing I wanted to speak to you about .
Parsing [sent. 428 len. 17]: You know -- dear me , what a very elegant button this is , Mr. Bumble !
Parsing [sent. 429 len. 7]: I never noticed it before . '
Parsing [sent. 430 len. 27]: ` Yes , I think it rather pretty , ' said the beadle , glancing proudly downwards at the large brass buttons which embellished his coat .
Parsing [sent. 431 len. 21]: ` The die is the same as the porochial seal -- the Good Samaritan healing the sick and bruised man .
Parsing [sent. 432 len. 14]: The board presented it to me on Newyear 's morning , Mr. Sowerberry .
Parsing [sent. 433 len. 32]: I put it on , I remember , for the first time , to attend the inquest on that reduced tradesman , who died in a doorway at midnight . ' '
Parsing [sent. 434 len. 8]: I recollect , ' said the undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 435 len. 30]: ` The jury brought it in , `` Died from exposure to the cold , and want of the common necessaries of life , '' did n't they ? '
Parsing [sent. 436 len. 4]: Mr. Bumble nodded .
Parsing [sent. 437 len. 37]: ` And they made it a special verdict , I think , ' said the undertaker , ` by adding some words to the effect , that if the relieving officer had -- ' ` Tush !
Parsing [sent. 438 len. 3]: Foolery ! '
Parsing [sent. 439 len. 4]: interposed the beadle .
Parsing [sent. 440 len. 22]: ` If the board attended to all the nonsense that ignorant jurymen talk , they 'd have enough to do . '
Parsing [sent. 441 len. 15]: ` Very true , ' said the undertaker ; ` they would indeed . '
Parsing [sent. 442 len. 34]: ` Juries , ' said Mr. Bumble , grasping his cane tightly , as was his wont when working into a passion : ` juries is ineddicated , vulgar , grovelling wretches . '
Parsing [sent. 443 len. 10]: ` So they are , ' said the undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 444 len. 25]: ` They have n't no more philosophy nor political economy about 'em than that , ' said the beadle , snapping his fingers contemptuously .
Parsing [sent. 445 len. 12]: ` No more they have , ' acquiesced the undertaker . '
Parsing [sent. 446 len. 16]: I despise 'em , ' said the beadle , growing very red in the face .
Parsing [sent. 447 len. 10]: ` So do I , ' rejoined the undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 448 len. 46]: ` And I only wish we 'd a jury of the independent sort , in the house for a week or two , ' said the beadle ; ` the rules and regulations of the board would soon bring their spirit down for 'em . '
Parsing [sent. 449 len. 12]: ` Let 'em alone for that , ' replied the undertaker .
Parsing [sent. 450 len. 19]: So saying , he smiled , approvingly : to calm the rising wrath of the indignant parish officer .
Parsing [sent. 451 len. 59]: Mr Bumble lifted off his cocked hat ; took a handkerchief from the inside of the crown ; wiped from his forehead the perspiration which his rage had engendered ; fixed the cocked hat on again ; and , turning to the undertaker , said in a calmer voice : ` Well ; what about the boy ? '
Parsing [sent. 452 len. 4]: ` Oh ! '
Parsing [sent. 453 len. 24]: replied the undertaker ; why , you know , Mr. Bumble , I pay a good deal towards the poor 's rates . '
Parsing [sent. 454 len. 4]: ` Hem ! '
Parsing [sent. 455 len. 4]: said Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 456 len. 4]: ` Well ? '
Parsing [sent. 457 len. 52]: ` Well , ' replied the undertaker , ' I was thinking that if I pay so much towards 'em , I 've a right to get as much out of 'em as I can , Mr. Bumble ; and so -- I think I 'll take the boy myself . '
Parsing [sent. 458 len. 16]: Mr. Bumble grasped the undertaker by the arm , and led him into the building .
Parsing [sent. 459 len. 87]: Mr. Sowerberry was closeted with the board for five minutes ; and it was arranged that Oliver should go to him that evening ` upon liking ' -- a phrase which means , in the case of a parish apprentice , that if the master find , upon a short trial , that he can get enough work out of a boy without putting too much food into him , he shall have him for a term of years , to do what he likes with .
Parsing [sent. 460 len. 101]: When little Oliver was taken before ` the gentlemen ' that evening ; and informed that he was to go , that night , as general house-lad to a coffin-maker 's ; and that if he complained of his situation , or ever came back to the parish again , he would be sent to sea , there to be drowned , or knocked on the head , as the case might be , he evinced so little emotion , that they by common consent pronounced him a hardened young rascal , and orered Mr. Bumble to remove him forthwith .
Parsing [sent. 461 len. 53]: Now , although it was very natural that the board , of all people in the world , should feel in a great state of virtuous astonishment and horror at the smallest tokens of want of feeling on the part of anybody , they were rather out , in this particular instance .
Parsing [sent. 462 len. 49]: The simple fact was , that Oliver , instead of possessing too little feeling , possessed rather too much ; and was in a fair way of being reduced , for life , to a state of brutal stupidity and sullenness by the ill usage he had received .
Parsing [sent. 463 len. 89]: He heard the news of his destination , in perfect silence ; and , having had his luggage put into his hand -- which was not very difficult to carry , inasmuch as it was all comprised within the limits of a brown paper parcel , about half a foot square by three inches deep -- he pulled his cap over his eyes ; and once more attaching himself to Mr. Bumble 's coat cuff , was led away by that dignitary to a new scene of suffering .
Parsing [sent. 464 len. 69]: For some time , Mr. Bumble drew Oliver along , without notice or remark ; for the beadle carried his head very erect , as a beadle always should : and , it being a windy day , little Oliver was completely enshrouded by the skirts of Mr. Bumble 's coat as they blew open , and disclosed to great advantage his flapped waistcoat and drab plush knee-breeches .
Parsing [sent. 465 len. 50]: As they drew near to their destination , however , Mr. Bumble thought it expedient to look down , and see that the boy was in good order for inspection by his new master : which he accordingly did , with a fit and becoming air of gracious patronage .
Parsing [sent. 466 len. 4]: ` Oliver ! '
Parsing [sent. 467 len. 4]: said Mr. Bumble .
Parsing [sent. 468 len. 16]: ` Yes , sir , ' replied Oliver , in a low , tremulous voice .
Parsing [sent. 469 len. 17]: ` Pull that cap off your eyes , and hold up your head , sir . '
Parsing [sent. 470 len. 38]: Although Oliver did as he was desired , at once ; and passed the back of his unoccupied hand briskly across his eyes , he left a tear in them when he looked up at his conductor .
Parsing [sent. 471 len. 14]: As Mr. Bumble gazed sternly upon him , it rolled down his cheek .
Parsing [sent. 472 len. 9]: It was followed by another , and another .
Parsing [sent. 473 len. 14]: The child made a strong effort , but it was an unsuccessful one .
Parsing [sent. 474 len. 30]: Withdrawing his other hand from Mr. Bumble 's he covered his face with both ; and wept until the tears sprung out from between his chin and bony fingers .
Parsing [sent. 475 len. 4]: ` Well ! '
Parsing [sent. 476 len. 19]: exclaimed Mr. Bumble , stopping short , and darting at his little charge a look of intense malignity .
Parsing [sent. 477 len. 3]: ` Well !
Parsing [sent. 478 len. 62]: Of ALL the ungratefullest , and worst-disposed boys as ever I see , Oliver , you are the -- ' ` No , no , sir , ' sobbed Oliver , clinging to the hand which held the well-known cane ; ` no , no , sir ; I will be good indeed ; indeed , indeed I will , sir !
Parsing [sent. 479 len. 22]: I am a very little boy , sir ; and it is so -- so -- ' ` So what ? '
Parsing [sent. 480 len. 6]: inquired Mr. Bumble in amazement .
Parsing [sent. 481 len. 6]: ` So lonely , sir !
Parsing [sent. 482 len. 5]: So very lonely ! '
Parsing [sent. 483 len. 4]: cried the child .
Parsing [sent. 484 len. 5]: ` Everybody hates me .
Parsing [sent. 485 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 486 len. 14]: sir , do n't , do n't pray be cross to me ! '
Parsing [sent. 487 len. 23]: The child beat his hand upon his heart ; and looked in his companion 's face , with tears of real agony .
Parsing [sent. 488 len. 51]: Mr. Bumble regarded Oliver 's piteous and helpless look , with some astonishment , for a few seconds ; hemmed three or four times in a husky manner ; and after muttering something about ` that troublesome cough , ' bade Oliver dry his eyes and be a good boy .
Parsing [sent. 489 len. 15]: Then once more taking his hand , he walked on with him in silence .
Parsing [sent. 490 len. 35]: The undertaker , who had just putup the shutters of his shop , was making some entries in his day-book by the light of a most appropriate dismal candle , when Mr. Bumble entered .
Parsing [sent. 491 len. 4]: ` Aha ! '
Parsing [sent. 492 len. 27]: said the undertaker ; looking up from the book , and pausing in the middle of a word ; ` is that you , Bumble ? '
Parsing [sent. 493 len. 13]: ` No one else , Mr. Sowerberry , ' replied the beadle .
Parsing [sent. 494 len. 3]: ` Here !
Parsing [sent. 495 len. 7]: I 've brought the boy . '
Parsing [sent. 496 len. 5]: Oliver made a bow .
Parsing [sent. 497 len. 3]: ` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 498 len. 9]: that 's the boy , is it ? '
Parsing [sent. 499 len. 19]: said the undertaker : raising the candle above his head , to get a better view of Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 500 len. 19]: ` Mrs. Sowerberry , will you have the goodness to come here a moment , my dear ? '

Parsing [sent. 502 len. 26]: ` My dear , ' said Mr. Sowerberry , deferentially , ` this is the boy from the workhouse that I told you of . '
Parsing [sent. 503 len. 4]: Oliver bowed again .
Parsing [sent. 504 len. 5]: ` Dear me ! '

Parsing [sent. 506 len. 33]: ` Why , he IS rather small , ' replied Mr. Bumble : looking at Oliver as if it were his fault that he was no bigger ; ` he is small .

Parsing [sent. 509 len. 3]: ` Ah !
Parsing [sent. 510 len. 20]: I dare say he will , ' replied the lady pettishly , ` on our victuals and our drink .
Parsing [sent. 511 len. 24]: I see no saving in parish children , not I ; for they always cost more to keep , than they 're worth .
Parsing [sent. 512 len. 9]: However , men always think they know best .
Parsing [sent. 513 len. 2]: There !

Parsing [sent. 515 len. 65]: With this , the undertaker 's wife opened a side door , and pushed Oliver down a steep flight of stairs into a stone cell , damp and dark : forming the ante-room to the coal-cellar , and denominated ` kitchen ' ; wherein sat a slatternly girl , in shoes down at heel , and blue worsted stockings very much out of repair .
Parsing [sent. 516 len. 32]: ` Here , Charlotte , ' said Mr. Sowerberry , who had followed Oliver down , ` give this boy some of the cold bits that were put by for Trip .
Parsing [sent. 517 len. 16]: He has n't come home since the morning , so he may go without 'em .
Parsing [sent. 518 len. 19]: I dare say the boy is n't too dainty to eat 'em -- are you , boy ? '
Parsing [sent. 519 len. 39]: Oliver , whose eyes had glistened at the mention of meat , and who was trembling with eagerness to devour it , replied in the negative ; and a plateful of coarse broken victuals was set before him .
Parsing [sent. 520 len. 42]: I wish some well-fed philosopher , whose meat and drink turn to gall within him ; whose blood is ice , whose heart is iron ; could have seen Oliver Twist clutching at the dainty viands that the dog had neglected .
Parsing [sent. 521 len. 23]: I wish he could have witnessed the horrible avidity with which Oliver tore the bits asunder with all the ferocity of famine .
Parsing [sent. 522 len. 31]: There is only one thing I should like better ; and that would be to see the Philosopher making the same sort of meal himself , with the same relish .
Parsing [sent. 523 len. 40]: ` Well , ' said the undertaker 's wife , when Oliver had finished his supper : which she had regarded in silent horror , and with fearful auguries of his future appetite : ` have you done ? '
Parsing [sent. 524 len. 14]: There being nothing eatable within his reach , Oliver replied in the affirmative .
Parsing [sent. 525 len. 33]: ` Then come with me , ' said Mrs. Sowerberry : taking up a dim and dirty lamp , and leading the way upstairs ; ` your bed 's under the counter .
Parsing [sent. 526 len. 12]: You do n't mind sleeping among the coffins , I suppose ?
Parsing [sent. 527 len. 21]: But it does n't much matter whether you do or do n't , for you ca n't sleep anywhere else .
Parsing [sent. 528 len. 11]: Come ; do n't keep me here all night ! '
Parsing [sent. 529 len. 12]: Oliver lingered no longer , but meekly followed his new mistress .
Parsing [sent. 530 len. 8]: CHAPTER V OLIVER MINGLES WITH NEW ASSOCIATES .
Parsing [sent. 531 len. 71]: GOING TO A FUNERAL FOR THE FIRST TIME , HE FORMS AN UNFAVOURABLE NOTION OF HIS MASTER 'S BUSINESS Oliver , being left to himself in the undertaker 's shop , set the lamp down on a workman 's bench , and gazed timidly about him with a feeling of awe and dread , which many people a good deal older than he will be at no loss to understand .
Parsing [sent. 532 len. 64]: An unfinished coffin on black tressels , which stood in the middle of the shop , looked so gloomy and death-like that a cold tremble came over him , every time his eyes wandered in the direction of the dismal object : from which he almost expected to see some frightful form slowly rear its head , to drive him mad with terror .
Parsing [sent. 533 len. 39]: Against the wall were ranged , in regular array , a long row of elm boards cut in the same shape : looking in the dim light , like high-shouldered ghosts with their hands in their breeches pockets .
Parsing [sent. 534 len. 61]: Coffin-plates , elm-chips , bright-headed nails , and shreds of black cloth , lay scattered on the floor ; and the wall behind the counter was ornamented with a lively representation of two mutes in very stiff neckcloths , on duty at a large private door , with a hearse drawn by four black steeds , approaching in the distance .
Parsing [sent. 535 len. 7]: The shop was close and hot .
Parsing [sent. 536 len. 10]: The atmosphere seemed tainted with the smell of coffins .
Parsing [sent. 537 len. 18]: The recess beneath the counter in which his flock mattress was thrust , looked like a grave .
Parsing [sent. 538 len. 11]: Nor were these the only dismal feelings which depressed Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 539 len. 28]: He was alone in a strange place ; and we all know how chilled and desolate the best of us will sometimes feel in such a situation .
Parsing [sent. 540 len. 15]: The boy had no friends to care for , or to care for him .
Parsing [sent. 541 len. 26]: The regret of no recent separation was fresh in his mind ; the absence of no loved and well-remembered face sank heavily into his heart .
Parsing [sent. 542 len. 68]: But his heart was heavy , notwithstanding ; and he wished , as he crept into his narrow bed , that that were his coffin , and that he could be lain in a calm and lasting sleep in the churchyard ground , with the tall grass waving gently above his head , and the sound of the old deep bell to soothe him in his sleep .
Parsing [sent. 543 len. 42]: Oliver was awakened in the morning , by a loud kicking at the outside of the shop-door : which , before he could huddle on his clothes , was repeated , in an angry and impetuous manner , about twenty-five times .
Parsing [sent. 544 len. 17]: When he began to undo the chain , the legs desisted , and a voice began .
Parsing [sent. 545 len. 9]: ` Open the door , will yer ? '
Parsing [sent. 546 len. 16]: cried the voice which belonged to the legs which had kicked at the door . '
Parsing [sent. 547 len. 21]: I will , directly , sir , ' replied Oliver : undoing the chain , and turning the key . '
Parsing [sent. 548 len. 12]: I suppose yer the new boy , ai n't yer ? '
Parsing [sent. 549 len. 7]: said the voice through the key-hole .
Parsing [sent. 550 len. 9]: ` Yes , sir , ' replied Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 551 len. 7]: ` How old are yer ? '
Parsing [sent. 552 len. 4]: inquired the voice .
Parsing [sent. 553 len. 9]: ` Ten , sir , ' replied Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 554 len. 36]: ` Then I 'll whop yer when I get in , ' said the voice ; ` you just see if I do n't , that 's all , my work ` us brat ! '
Parsing [sent. 555 len. 13]: and having made this obliging promise , the voice began to whistle .
Parsing [sent. 556 len. 45]: Oliver had been too often subjected to the process to which the very expressive monosyllable just recorded bears reference , to entertain the smallest doubt that the owner of the voice , whoever he might be , would redeem his pledge , most honourably .
Parsing [sent. 557 len. 15]: He drew back the bolts with a trembling hand , and opened the door .
Parsing [sent. 558 len. 101]: For a second or two , Oliver glanced up the street , and down the street , and over the way : impressed with the belief that the unknown , who had addressed him through the key-hole , had walked a few paces off , to warm himself ; for nobody did he see but a big charity-boy , sitting on a post in front of the house , eating a slice of bread and butter : which he cut into wedges , the size of his mouth , with a clasp-knife , and then consumed with great dexterity . '
Parsing [sent. 559 len. 29]: I beg your pardon , sir , ' said Oliver at length : seeing that no other visitor made his appearance ; ` did you knock ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 560 len. 8]: I kicked , ' replied the charity-boy .
Parsing [sent. 561 len. 10]: ` Did you want a coffin , sir ? '
Parsing [sent. 562 len. 5]: inquired Oliver , innocently .
Parsing [sent. 563 len. 30]: At this , the charity-boy looked monstrous fierce ; and said that Oliver would want one before long , if he cut jokes with his superiors in that way .
Parsing [sent. 564 len. 17]: ` Yer do n't know who I am , I suppose , Work ` us ? '
Parsing [sent. 565 len. 21]: said the charity-boy , in continuation : descending from the top of the post , meanwhile , with edifying gravity .
Parsing [sent. 566 len. 9]: ` No , sir , ' rejoined Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 567 len. 19]: ` I 'm Mister Noah Claypole , ' said the charity-boy , ` and you 're under me .
Parsing [sent. 568 len. 11]: Take down the shutters , yer idle young ruffian ! '
Parsing [sent. 569 len. 26]: With this , Mr. Claypole administered a kick to Oliver , and entered the shop with a dignified air , which did him great credit .
Parsing [sent. 570 len. 45]: It is difficult for a large-headed , small-eyed youth , of lumbering make and heavy countenance , to look dignified under any circumstances ; but it is more especially so , when superadded to these personal attractions are a red nose and yellow smalls .
Parsing [sent. 571 len. 72]: Oliver , having taken down the shutters , and broken a pane of glass in his effort to stagger away beneath the weight of the first one to a small court at the side of the house in which they were kept during the day , was graciously assisted by Noah : who having consoled him with the assurance that ` he 'd catch it , ' condescended to help him .
Parsing [sent. 572 len. 7]: Mr. Sowerberry came down soon after .
Parsing [sent. 573 len. 7]: Shortly afterwards , Mrs. Sowerberry appeared .
Parsing [sent. 574 len. 24]: Oliver having ` caught it , ' in fulfilment of Noah 's prediction , followed that young gentleman down the stairs to breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 575 len. 13]: ` Come near the fire , Noah , ' said Charlotte . '
Parsing [sent. 576 len. 15]: I saved a nice little bit of bacon for you from master 's breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 577 len. 27]: Oliver , shut that door at Mister Noah 's back , and take them bits that I 've put out on the cover of the bread-pan .
Parsing [sent. 578 len. 31]: There 's your tea ; take it away to that box , and drink it there , and make haste , for they 'll want you to mind the shop .
Parsing [sent. 579 len. 4]: D'ye hear ? '
Parsing [sent. 580 len. 10]: 'D ` ye hear , Work ` us ? '
Parsing [sent. 581 len. 4]: said Noah Claypole .
Parsing [sent. 582 len. 6]: ` Lor , Noah ! '
Parsing [sent. 583 len. 11]: said Charlotte , ` what a rum creature you are !
Parsing [sent. 584 len. 10]: Why do n't you let the boy alone ? '
Parsing [sent. 585 len. 6]: ` Let him alone ! '
Parsing [sent. 586 len. 3]: said Noah .
Parsing [sent. 587 len. 14]: ` Why everybody lets him alone enough , for the matter of that .
Parsing [sent. 588 len. 12]: Neither his father nor his mother will ever interfere with him .
Parsing [sent. 589 len. 12]: All his relations let him have his own way pretty well .
Parsing [sent. 590 len. 4]: Eh , Charlotte ?
Parsing [sent. 591 len. 2]: He !
Parsing [sent. 592 len. 2]: he !
Parsing [sent. 593 len. 3]: he ! '
Parsing [sent. 594 len. 8]: ` Oh , you queer soul ! '
Parsing [sent. 595 len. 56]: said Charlotte , bursting into a hearty laugh , in which she was joined by Noah ; after which they both looked scornfully at poor Oliver Twist , as he sat shivering on the box in the coldest corner of the room , and ate the stale pieces which had been specially reserved for him .
Parsing [sent. 596 len. 11]: Noah was a charity-boy , but not a workhouse orphan .
Parsing [sent. 597 len. 54]: No chance-child was he , for he could trace his genealogy all the way back to his parents , who lived hard by ; his mother being a washerwoman , and his father a drunken soldier , discharged with a wooden leg , and a diurnal pension of twopence-halfpenny and an unstateable fraction .
Parsing [sent. 598 len. 44]: The shop-boys in the neighbourhood had long been in the habit of branding Noah in the public streets , with the ignominious epithets of ` leathers , ' ` charity , ' and the like ; and Noah had bourne them without reply .
Parsing [sent. 599 len. 33]: But , now that fortune had cast in his way a nameless orphan , at whom even the meanest could point the finger of scorn , he retorted on him with interest .
Parsing [sent. 600 len. 7]: This affords charming food for contemplation .
Parsing [sent. 601 len. 33]: It shows us what a beautiful thing human nature may be made to be ; and how impartially the same amiable qualities are developed in the finest lord and the dirtiest charity-boy .
Parsing [sent. 602 len. 15]: Oliver had been sojourning at the undertaker 's some three weeks or a month .
Parsing [sent. 603 len. 63]: Mr. and Mrs. Sowerberry -- the shop being shut up -- were taking their supper in the little back-parlour , when Mr. Sowerberry , after several deferential glances at his wife , said , ` My dear -- ' He was going to say more ; but , Mrs. Sowerberry looking up , with a peculiarly unpropitious aspect , he stopped short .
Parsing [sent. 604 len. 10]: ` Well , ' said Mrs. Sowerberry , sharply .
Parsing [sent. 605 len. 13]: ` Nothing , my dear , nothing , ' said Mr. Sowerberry .
Parsing [sent. 606 len. 7]: ` Ugh , you brute ! '

Parsing [sent. 669 len. 61]: The houses on either side were high and large , but very old , and tenanted by people of the poorest class : as their neglected appearance would have sufficiently dentoed , without the concurrent testimony afforded by the squalid looks of the few men and women who , with folded arms and bodies half doubled , occasionally skulked along .
Parsing [sent. 670 len. 26]: A great many of the tenements had shop-fronts ; but these were fast closed , and mouldering away ; only the upper rooms being inhabited .
Parsing [sent. 671 len. 90]: Some houses which had become insecure from age and decay , were prevented from falling into the street , by huge beams of wood reared against the walls , and firmly planted in the road ; but even these crazy dens seemed to have been selected as the nightly haunts of some houseless wretches , for many of the rough boards which supplied the place of door and window , were wrenched from their positions , to afford an aperture wide enough for the passage of a human body .

Parsing [sent. 734 len. 80]: There was not so great a necessity for hurrying as Mr. Sowerberry had anticipated , however ; for when they reached the obscure corner of the churchyard in which the nettles grew , and where the parish graves were made , the clergyman had not arrived ; and the clerk , who was sitting by the vestry-room fire , seemed to think it by no means improbable that it might be an hour or so , before he came .
Parsing [sent. 735 len. 66]: So , they put the bier on the brink of the grave ; and the two mourners waited patiently in the damp clay , with a cold rain drizzling down , while the ragged boys whom the spectacle had attracted into the churchyard played a noisy game at hide-and-seek among the tombstones , or varied their amusements by jumping backwards and forwards over the coffin .

Parsing [sent. 757 len. 31]: CHAPTER VI OLIVER , BEING GOADED BY THE TAUNTS OF NOAH , ROUSES INTO ACTION , AND RATHER ASTONISHES HIM The month 's trial over , Oliver was formally apprenticed .
Parsing [sent. 758 len. 11]: It was a nice sickly season just at this time .
Parsing [sent. 759 len. 27]: In commercial phrase , coffins were looking up ; and , in the course of a few weeks , Oliver acquired a great deal of experience .
Parsing [sent. 760 len. 16]: The success of Mr. Sowerberry 's ingenious speculation , exceeded even his most sanguine hopes .
Parsing [sent. 761 len. 55]: The oldest inhabitants recollected no period at which measles had been so prevalent , or so fatal to infant existence ; and many were the mournful processions which little Oliver headed , in a hat-band reaching down to his knees , to the indescribable admiration and emotion of all the mothers in the town .
Parsing [sent. 762 len. 58]: As Oliver accompanied his master in most of his adult expeditions too , in order that he might acquire that equanimity of demeanour and full command of nerve which was essential to a finished undertaker , he had many opportunities of observing the beautiful resignation and fortitude with which some strong-minded people bear their trials and losses .
Parsing [sent. 763 len. 90]: For instance ; when Sowerberry had an order for the burial of some rich old lady or gentleman , who was surrounded by a great number of nephews and nieces , who had been perfectly inconsolable during the previous illness , and whose grief had been wholly irrepressible even on the most public occasions , they would be as happy among themselves as need be -- quite cheerful and contented -- conversing together with as much freedom and gaiety , as if nothing whatever had happened to disturb them .
Parsing [sent. 764 len. 16]: Husbands , too , bore the loss of their wives with the most heroic calmness .
Parsing [sent. 765 len. 40]: Wives , again , put on weeds for their husbands , as if , so far from grieving in the garb of sorrow , they had made up their minds to render it as becoming and attractive as possible .
Parsing [sent. 766 len. 41]: It was observable , too , that ladies and gentlemen who were in passions of anguish during the ceremony of interment , recovered almost as soon as they reached home , and became quite composed before the tea-drinking was over .
Parsing [sent. 767 len. 18]: All this was very pleasant and improving to see ; and Oliver beheld it with great admiration .
Parsing [sent. 768 len. 101]: That Oliver Twist was moved to resignation by the example of these good people , I can not , although I am his biographer , undertake to affirm with any degree of confidence ; but I can most distinctly say , that for many months he continued meekly to submit to the domination and ill-treatment of Noah Claypole : who used him far worse than before , now that his jealousy was roused by seeing the new boy promoted to the black stick and hatband , while he , the old one , remained stationary in the muffin-cap and leathers .
Parsing [sent. 769 len. 74]: Charlotte treated him ill , because Noah did ; and Mrs. Sowerberry was his decided enemy , because Mr. Sowerberry was disposed to be his friend ; so , between these three on one side , and a glut of funerals on the other , Oliver was not altogether as comfortable as the hungry pig was , when he was shut up , by mistake , in the grain department of a brewery .
Parsing [sent. 770 len. 45]: And now , I come to a very important passage in Oliver 's history ; for I have to record an act , slight and unimportant perhaps in appearance , but which indirectly produced a material change in all his future prospects and proceedings .
Parsing [sent. 771 len. 82]: One day , Oliver and Noah had descended into the kitchen at the usual dinner-hour , to banquet upon a small joint of mutton -- a pound and a half of the worst end of the neck -- when Charlotte being called out of the way , there ensued a brief interval of time , which Noah Claypole , being hungry and vicious , considered he could not possibly devote to a worthier purpose than aggravating and tantalising young Oliver Twist .
Parsing [sent. 772 len. 76]: Intent upon this innocent amusement , Noah put his feet on the table-cloth ; and pulled Oliver 's hair ; and twitched his ears ; and expressed his opinion that he was a ` sneak ' ; and furthermore announced his intention of coming to see him hanged , whenever that desirable event should take place ; and entered upon various topics of petty annoyance , like a malicious and ill-conditioned charity-boy as he was .
Parsing [sent. 773 len. 35]: But , making Oliver cry , Noah attempted to be more facetious still ; and in his attempt , did what many sometimes do to this day , when they want to be funny .

Parsing [sent. 797 len. 82]: ` Yer know , Work ` us , ' continued Noah , emboldened by Oliver 's silence , and speaking in a jeering tone of affected pity : of all tones the most annoying : ` Yer know , Work ` us , it ca n't be helped now ; and of course yer could n't help it then ; and I am very sorry for it ; and I 'm sure we all are , and pity yer very much .

Parsing [sent. 803 len. 54]: Crimson with fury , Oliver started up ; overthrew the chair and table ; seized Noah by the throat ; shook him , in the violence of his rage , till his teeth chattered in his head ; and collecting his whole force into one heavy blow , felled him to the ground .
