Parsing [sent. 3815 len. 2]: Alas !
Parsing [sent. 3816 len. 16]: How few of Nature 's faces are left alone to gladden us with their beauty !
Parsing [sent. 3817 len. 51]: The cares , and sorrows , and hungerings , of the world , change them as they change hearts ; and it is only when those passions sleep , and have lost their hold for ever , that the troubled clouds pass off , and leave Heaven 's surface clear .
Parsing [sent. 3818 len. 78]: It is a common thing for the countenances of the dead , even in that fixed and rigid state , to subside into the long-forgotten expression of sleeping infancy , and settle into the very look of early life ; so calm , so peaceful , do they grow again , that those who knew them in their happy childhood , kneel by the coffin 's side in awe , and see the Angel even upon earth .

Parsing [sent. 3944 len. 49]: CHAPTER XXV WHEREIN THIS HISTORY REVERTS TO MR. FAGIN AND COMPANY While these things were passing in the country workhouse , Mr. Fagin sat in the old den -- the same from which Oliver had been removed by the girl -- brooding over a dull , smoky fire .
Parsing [sent. 3945 len. 60]: He held a pair of bellows upon his knee , with which he had apparently been endeavouring to rouse it into more cheerful action ; but he had fallen into deep thought ; and with his arms folded on them , and his chin resting on his thumbs , fixed his eyes , abstractedly , on the rusty bars .
Parsing [sent. 3946 len. 37]: At a table behind him sat the Artful Dodger , Master Charles Bates , and Mr. Chitling : all intent upon a game of whist ; the Artful taking dummy against Master Bates and Mr. Chitling .
Parsing [sent. 3947 len. 72]: The countenance of the first-named gentleman , peculiarly intelligent at all times , acquired great additional interest from his close observance of the game , and his attentive perusal of Mr. Chitling 's hand ; upon which , from time to time , as occasion served , he bestowed a variety of earnest glances : wisely regulating his own play by the result of his observations upon his neighbour 's cards .
Parsing [sent. 3948 len. 23]: It being a cold night , the Dodger wore his hat , as , indeed , was often his custom within doors .
Parsing [sent. 3949 len. 48]: He also sustained a clay pipe between his teeth , which he only removed for a brief space when he deemed it necessary to apply for refreshment to a quart pot upon the table , which stood ready filled with gin-and-water for the accommodation of the company .
Parsing [sent. 3950 len. 51]: Master Bates was also attentive to the play ; but being of a more excitable nature than his accomplished friend , it was observable that he more frequently applied himself to the gin-and-water , and moreover indulged in many jests and irrelevant remarks , all highly unbecoming a scientific rubber .
Parsing [sent. 3951 len. 86]: Indeed , the Artful , presuming upon their close attachment , more than once took occasion to reason gravely with his companion upon these improprieties ; all of which remonstrances , Master Bates received in extremely good part ; merely requesting his friend to be ` blowed , ' or to insert his head in a sack , or replying with some other neatly-turned witticism of a similar kind , the happy application of which , excited considerable admiration in the mind of Mr. Chitling .
Parsing [sent. 3952 len. 63]: It was remarkable that the latter gentleman and his partner invariably lost ; and that the circumstance , so far from angering Master Bates , appeared to afford him the highest amusement , inasmuch as he laughed most uproariously at the end of every deal , and protested that he had never seen such a jolly game in all his born days .
Parsing [sent. 3953 len. 29]: ` That 's two doubles and the rub , ' said Mr. Chitling , with a very long face , as he drew half-a-crown from his waistcoat-pocket . '
Parsing [sent. 3954 len. 15]: I never see such a feller as you , Jack ; you win everything .

Parsing [sent. 4096 len. 38]: Near to the spot on which Snow Hill and Holborn Hill meet , opens , upon the right hand as you come out of the City , a narrow and dismal alley , leading to Saffron Hill .
Parsing [sent. 4097 len. 32]: In its filthy shops are exposed for sale huge bunches of second-hand silk handkerchiefs , of all sizes and patterns ; for here reside the traders who purchase them from pick-pockets .
Parsing [sent. 4098 len. 28]: Hundreds of these handkerchiefs hang dangling from pegs outside the windows or flaunting from the door-posts ; and the shelves , within , are piled with them .
Parsing [sent. 4099 len. 25]: Confined as the limits of Field Lane are , it has its barber , its coffee-shop , its beer-shop , and its fried-fish warehouse .
Parsing [sent. 4100 len. 43]: It is a commercial colony of itself : the emporium of petty larceny : visited at early morning , and setting-in of dusk , by silent merchants , who traffic in dark back-parlours , and who go as strangely as they come .
Parsing [sent. 4101 len. 50]: Here , the clothesman , the shoe-vamper , and the rag-merchant , display their goods , as sign-boards to the petty thief ; here , stores of old iron and bones , and heaps of mildewy fragments of woollen-stuff and linen , rust and rot in the grimy cellars .

Parsing [sent. 4131 len. 42]: The ceiling was blackened , to prevent its colour from being injured by the flaring of the lamps ; and the place was so full of dense tobacco smoke , that at first it was scarcely possible to discern anything more .
Parsing [sent. 4132 len. 120]: By degrees , however , as some of it cleared away through the open door , an assemblage of heads , as confused as the noises that greeted the ear , might be made out ; and as the eye grew more accustomed to the scene , the spectator gradually became aware of the presence of a numerous company , male and female , crowded round a long table : at the upper end of which , sat a chairman with a hammer of office in his hand ; while a professional gentleman with a bluish nose , and his face tied up for the benefit of a toothache , presided at a jingling piano in a remote corner .
Parsing [sent. 4133 len. 66]: As Fagin stepped softly in , the professional gentleman , running over the keys by way of prelude , occasioned a general cry of order for a song ; which having subsided , a young lady proceeded to entertain the company with a ballad in four verses , between each of which the accompanyist played the melody all through , as loud as he could .
Parsing [sent. 4134 len. 36]: When this was over , the chairman gave a sentiment , after which , the professional gentleman on the chairman 's right and left volunteered a duet , and sang it , with great applause .

Parsing [sent. 4137 len. 65]: Near him were the singers : receiving , with professional indifference , the compliments of the company , and applying themselves , in turn , to a dozen proffered glasses of spirits and water , tendered by their more boisterous admirers ; whose countenances , expressive of almost every vice in almost every grade , irresistibly attracted the attention , by their very repulsiveness .
Parsing [sent. 4138 len. 90]: Cunning , ferocity , and drunkeness in all its stages , were there , in their strongest aspect ; and women : some with the last lingering tinge of their early freshness almost fading as you looked : others with every mark and stamp of their sex utterly beaten out , and presenting but one loathsome blank of profligacy and crime ; some mere girls , others but young women , and none past the prime of life ; formed the darkest and saddest portion of this dreary picture .

Parsing [sent. 4368 len. 215]: CHAPTER XXVII ATONES FOR THE UNPOLITENESS OF A FORMER CHAPTER ; WHICH DESERTED A LADY , MOST UNCEREMONIOUSLY As it would be , by no means , seemly in a humble author to keep so mighty a personage as a beadle waiting , with his back to the fire , and the skirts of his coat gathered up under his arms , until such time as it might suit his pleasure to relieve him ; and as it would still less become his station , or his gallentry to involve in the same neglect a lady on whom that beadle had looked with an eye of tenderness and affection , and in whose ear he had whispered sweet words , which , coming from such a quarter , might well thrill the bosom of maid or matron of whatsoever degree ; the historian whose pen traces these words -- trusting that he knows his place , and that he entertains a becoming reverence for those upon earth to whom high and important authority is delegated -- hastens to pay them that respect which their position demands , and to treat them with all that duteous ceremony which their exalted rank , and -LRB- by consequence -RRB- great virtues , imperatively claim at his hands .
Parsing [sent. 4369 len. 187]: Towards this end , indeed , he had purposed to introduce , in this place , a dissertation touching the divine right of beadles , and elucidative of the position , that a beadle can do no wrong : which could not fail to have been both pleasurable and profitable to the right-minded reader but which he is unfortunately compelled , by want of time and space , to postpone to some more convenient and fitting opportunity ; on the arrival of which , he will be prepared to show , that a beadle properly constituted : that is to say , a parochial beadle , attached to a parochail workhouse , and attending in his official capacity the parochial church : is , in right and virtue of his office , possessed of all the excellences and best qualities of humanity ; and that to none of those excellences , can mere companies ' beadles , or court-of-law beadles , or even chapel-of-ease beadles -LRB- save the last , and they in a very lowly and inferior degree -RRB- , lay the remotest sustainable claim .
Parsing [sent. 4370 len. 67]: Mr. Bumble had re-counted the teaspoons , re-weighed the sugar-tongs , made a closer inspection of the milk-pot , and ascertained to a nicety the exact condition of the furniture , down to the very horse-hair seats of the chairs ; and had repeated each process full half a dozen times ; before he began to think that it was time for Mrs. Corney to return .
Parsing [sent. 4371 len. 57]: Thinking begets thinking ; as there were no sounds of Mrs. Corney 's approach , it occured to Mr. Bumble that it would be an innocent and virtuous way of spending the time , if he were further to allay his curiousity by a cursory glance at the interior of Mrs. Corney 's chest of drawers .
Parsing [sent. 4372 len. 72]: Having listened at the keyhole , to assure himself that nobody was approaching the chamber , Mr. Bumble , beginning at the bottom , proceeded to make himself acquainted with the contents of the three long drawers : which , being filled with various garments of good fashion and texture , carefully preserved between two layers of old newspapers , speckled with dried lavender : seemed to yield him exceeding satisfaction .

Parsing [sent. 4853 len. 112]: if when we oppress and grind our fellow-creatures , we bestowed but one thought on the dark evidences of human error , which , like dense and heavy clouds , are rising , slowly it is true , but not less surely , to Heaven , to pour their after-vengeance on our heads ; if we heard but one instant , in imagination , the deep testimony of dead men 's voices , which no power can stifle , and no pride shut out ; where would be the injury and injustice , the suffering , misery , cruelty , and wrong , that each day 's life brings with it !

Parsing [sent. 5062 len. 18]: Jem Spyers dashes out ; and there he sees Chickweed , a-tearing down the street full cry .
Parsing [sent. 5063 len. 21]: Away goes Spyers ; on goes Chickweed ; round turns the people ; everybody roars out , `` Thieves ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5064 len. 14]: and Chickweed himself keeps on shouting , all the time , like mad .
Parsing [sent. 5065 len. 31]: Spyers loses sight of him a minute as he turns a corner ; shoots round ; sees a little crowd ; dives in ; `` Which is the man ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5066 len. 6]: `` D -- me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5067 len. 11]: says Chickweed , `` I 've lost him again ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5068 len. 23]: It was a remarkable occurrence , but he war n't to be seen nowhere , so they went back to the public-house .
Parsing [sent. 5069 len. 38]: Next morning , Spyers took his old place , and looked out , from behind the curtain , for a tall man with a black patch over his eye , till his own two eyes ached again .
Parsing [sent. 5070 len. 36]: At last , he could n't help shutting 'em , to ease 'em a minute ; and the very moment he did so , he hears Chickweed a-roaring out , `` Here he is ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5071 len. 35]: Off he starts once more , with Chickweed half-way down the street ahead of him ; and after twice as long a run as the yesterday 's one , the man 's lost again !
Parsing [sent. 5072 len. 49]: This was done , once or twice more , till one-half the neighbours gave out that Mr. Chickweed had been robbed by the devil , who was playing tricks with him arterwards ; and the other half , that poor Mr. Chickweed had gone mad with grief . '
Parsing [sent. 5073 len. 8]: ` What did Jem Spyers say ? '
Parsing [sent. 5074 len. 18]: inquired the doctor ; who had returned to the room shortly after the commencement of the story .
Parsing [sent. 5075 len. 34]: ` Jem Spyers , ' resumed the officer , ` for a long time said nothing at all , and listened to everything without seeming to , which showed he understood his business .
Parsing [sent. 5076 len. 32]: But , one morning , he walked into the bar , and taking out his snuffbox , says `` Chickweed , I 've found out who done this here robbery . ''
Parsing [sent. 5077 len. 5]: `` Have you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5078 len. 3]: said Chickweed .
Parsing [sent. 5079 len. 19]: `` Oh , my dear Spyers , only let me have wengeance , and I shall die contented !
Parsing [sent. 5080 len. 12]: Oh , my dear Spyers , where is the villain ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5081 len. 4]: `` Come ! ''
Parsing [sent. 5082 len. 16]: said Spyers , offering him a pinch of snuff , `` none of that gammon !
Parsing [sent. 5083 len. 6]: You did it yourself . ''
Parsing [sent. 5084 len. 41]: So he had ; and a good bit of money he had made by it , too ; and nobody would never have found it out , if he had n't been so precious anxious to keep up appearances ! '
Parsing [sent. 5085 len. 15]: said Mr. Blathers , putting down his wine-glass , and clinking the handcuffs together .
Parsing [sent. 5086 len. 11]: ` Very curious , indeed , ' observed the doctor .
Parsing [sent. 5087 len. 13]: ` Now , if you please , you can walk upstairs . '
Parsing [sent. 5088 len. 12]: ` If YOU please , sir , ' returned Mr. Blathers .
Parsing [sent. 5089 len. 25]: Closely following Mr. Losberne , the two officers ascended to Oliver 's bedroom ; Mr. Giles preceding the party , with a lighted candle .
Parsing [sent. 5090 len. 19]: Oliver had been dozing ; but looked worse , and was more feverish than he had appeared yet .
Parsing [sent. 5091 len. 50]: Being assisted by the doctor , he managed to sit up in bed for a minute or so ; and looked at the strangers without at all understanding what was going forward -- in fact , without seeming to recollect where he was , or what had been passing .
Parsing [sent. 5092 len. 93]: ` This , ' said Mr. Losberne , speaking softly , but with great vehemence notwithstanding , ` this is the lad , who , being accidently wounded by a spring-gun in some boyish trespass on Mr. What-d ' ye-call-him 's grounds , at the back here , comes to the house for assistance this morning , and is immediately laid hold of and maltreated , by that ingenious gentleman with the candle in his hand : who has placed his life in considerable danger , as I can professionally certify . '
Parsing [sent. 5093 len. 18]: Messrs. Blathers and Duff looked at Mr. Giles , as he was thus recommended to their notice .
Parsing [sent. 5094 len. 26]: The bewildered butler gazed from them towards Oliver , and from Oliver towards Mr. Losberne , with a most ludicrous mixture of fear and perplexity .
Parsing [sent. 5095 len. 13]: ` You do n't mean to deny that , I suppose ? '
Parsing [sent. 5096 len. 10]: said the doctor , laying Oliver gently down again .
Parsing [sent. 5097 len. 19]: ` It was all done for the -- for the best , sir , ' answered Giles . '
Parsing [sent. 5098 len. 19]: I am sure I thought it was the boy , or I would n't have meddled with him .
Parsing [sent. 5099 len. 11]: I am not of an inhuman disposition , sir . '

Parsing [sent. 5103 len. 3]: replied Giles .

Parsing [sent. 5112 len. 21]: I do n't know ; I really do n't know , ' said Giles , with a rueful countenance . '
Parsing [sent. 5113 len. 8]: I could n't swear to him . '
Parsing [sent. 5114 len. 7]: ` What do you think ? '
Parsing [sent. 5115 len. 5]: asked Mr. Blathers . '
Parsing [sent. 5116 len. 14]: I do n't know what to think , ' replied poor Giles . '
Parsing [sent. 5117 len. 20]: I do n't think it is the boy ; indeed , I 'm almost certain that it is n't .
Parsing [sent. 5118 len. 8]: You know it ca n't be . '

Parsing [sent. 5121 len. 10]: ` What a precious muddle-headed chap you are ! '
Parsing [sent. 5122 len. 11]: said Duff , addressing Mr. Giles , with supreme contempt .
Parsing [sent. 5123 len. 56]: Mr. Losberne had been feeling the patient 's pulse during this short dialogue ; but he now rose from the chair by the bedside , and remarked , that if the officers had any doubts upon the subject , they would perhaps like to step into the next room , and have Brittles before them .
Parsing [sent. 5124 len. 129]: Acting upon this suggestion , they adjourned to a neighbouring apartment , where Mr. Brittles , being called in , involved himself and his respected superior in such a wonderful maze of fresh contradictions and impossibilities , as tended to throw no particular light on anything , but the fact of his own strong mystification ; except , indeed , his declarations that he should n't know the real boy , if he were put before him that instant ; that he had only taken Oliver to be he , because Mr. Giles had said he was ; and that Mr. Giles had , five minutes previously , admitted in the kitchen , that he begain to be very much afraid he had been a little too hasty .
Parsing [sent. 5125 len. 71]: Among other ingenious surmises , the question was then raised , whether Mr. Giles had really hit anybody ; and upon examination of the fellow pistol to that which he had fired , it turned out to have no more destructive loading than gunpowder and brown paper : a discovery which made a considerable impression on everybody but the doctor , who had drawn the ball about ten minutes before .
Parsing [sent. 5126 len. 51]: Upon no one , however , did it make a greater impression than on Mr. Giles himself ; who , after labouring , for some hours , under the fear of having mortally wounded a fellow-creature , eagerly caught at this new idea , and favoured it to the utmost .
Parsing [sent. 5127 len. 40]: Finally , the officers , without troubling themselves very much about Oliver , left the Chertsey constable in the house , and took up their rest for that night in the town ; promising to return the next morning .
Parsing [sent. 5128 len. 43]: With the next morning , there came a rumour , that two men and a boy were in the cage at Kingston , who had been apprehended over night under suspicious circumstances ; and to Kingston Messrs. Blathers and Duff journeyed accordingly .
Parsing [sent. 5129 len. 118]: The suspicious circumstances , however , resolving themselves , on investigation , into the one fact , that they had been discovered sleeping under a haystack ; which , although a great crime , is only punishable by imprisonment , and is , in the merciful eye of the English law , and its comprehensive love of all the King 's subjects , held to be no satisfactory proof , in the absence of all other evidence , that the sleeper , or sleepers , have committed burglary accompanied with violence , and have therefore rendered themselves liable to the punishment of death ; Messrs. Blathers and Duff came back again , as wise as they went .
Parsing [sent. 5130 len. 117]: In short , after some more examination , and a great deal more conversation , a neighbouring magistrate was readily induced to take the joint bail of Mrs. Maylie and Mr. Losberne for Oliver 's appearance if he should ever be called upon ; and Blathers and Duff , being rewarded with a couple of guineas , returned to town with divided opinions on the subject of their expedition : the latter gentleman on a mature consideration of all the circumstances , inclining to the belief that the burglarious attempt had originated with the Family Pet ; and the former being equally disposed to concede the full merit of it to the great Mr. Conkey Chickweed .
Parsing [sent. 5131 len. 23]: Meanwhile , Oliver gradually throve and prospered under the united care of Mrs. Maylie , Rose , and the kind-hearted Mr. Losberne .
Parsing [sent. 5132 len. 26]: If fervent prayers , gushing from hearts overcharged with gratitude , be heard in heaven -- and if they be not , what prayers are !
Parsing [sent. 5133 len. 22]: -- the blessings which the orphan child called down upon them , sunk into their souls , diffusing peace and happiness .
Parsing [sent. 5134 len. 23]: CHAPTER XXXII OF THE HAPPY LIFE OLIVER BEGAN TO LEAD WITH HIS KIND FRIENDS Oliver 's ailings were neither slight nor few .
Parsing [sent. 5135 len. 40]: In addition to the pain and delay attendant on a broken limb , his exposure to the wet and cold had brought on fever and ague : which hung about him for many weeks , and reduced him sadly .
Parsing [sent. 5136 len. 132]: But , at length , he began , by slow degrees , to get better , and to be able to say sometimes , in a few tearful words , how deeply he felt the goodness of the two sweet ladies , and how ardently he hoped that when he grew strong and well again , he could do something to show his gratitude ; only something , which would let them see the love and duty with which his breast was full ; something , however slight , which would prove to them that their gentle kindness had not been cast away ; but that the poor boy whom their charity had rescued from misery , or death , was eager to serve them with his whole heart and soul .
Parsing [sent. 5137 len. 5]: ` Poor fellow ! '
Parsing [sent. 5138 len. 38]: said Rose , when Oliver had been one day feebly endeavouring to utter the words of thankfulness that rose to his pale lips ; ` you shall have many opportunities of serving us , if you will .
Parsing [sent. 5139 len. 17]: We are going into the country , and my aunt intends that you shall accompany us .
Parsing [sent. 5140 len. 25]: The quiet place , the pure air , and all the pleasure and beauties of spring , will restore you in a few days .
Parsing [sent. 5141 len. 17]: We will employ you in a hundred ways , when you can bear the trouble . '
Parsing [sent. 5142 len. 5]: ` The trouble ! '
Parsing [sent. 5143 len. 3]: cried Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5144 len. 3]: ` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5145 len. 52]: dear lady , if I could but work for you ; if I could only give you pleasure by watering your flowers , or watching your birds , or running up and down the whole day long , to make you happy ; what would I give to do it ! '
Parsing [sent. 5146 len. 59]: ` You shall give nothing at all , ' said Miss Maylie , smiling ; ` for , as I told you before , we shall employ you in a hundred ways ; and if you only take half the trouble to please us , that you promise now , you will make me very happy indeed . '
Parsing [sent. 5147 len. 6]: ` Happy , ma'am ! '
Parsing [sent. 5148 len. 13]: cried Oliver ; ` how kind of you to say so ! '
Parsing [sent. 5149 len. 18]: ` You will make me happier than I can tell you , ' replied the young lady .
Parsing [sent. 5150 len. 67]: ` To think that my dear good aunt should have been the means of rescuing any one from such sad misery as you have described to us , would be an unspeakable pleasure to me ; but to know that the object of her goodness and compassion was sincerely grateful and attached , in consequence , would delight me , more than you can well imagine .
Parsing [sent. 5151 len. 6]: Do you understand me ? '
Parsing [sent. 5152 len. 9]: she inquired , watching Oliver 's thoughtful face .
Parsing [sent. 5153 len. 9]: ` Oh yes , ma'am , yes ! '
Parsing [sent. 5154 len. 16]: replied Oliver eagerly ; ` but I was thinking that I am ungrateful now . '
Parsing [sent. 5155 len. 5]: ` To whom ? '
Parsing [sent. 5156 len. 5]: inquired the young lady .
Parsing [sent. 5157 len. 25]: ` To the kind gentleman , and the dear old nurse , who took so much care of me before , ' rejoined Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5158 len. 20]: ` If they knew how happy I am , they would be pleased , I am sure . ' '
Parsing [sent. 5159 len. 43]: I am sure they would , ' rejoined Oliver 's benefactress ; ` and Mr. Losberne has already been kind enough to promise that when you are well enough to bear the journey , he will carry you to see them . '
Parsing [sent. 5160 len. 7]: ` Has he , ma'am ? '
Parsing [sent. 5161 len. 10]: cried Oliver , his face brightening with pleasure . '
Parsing [sent. 5162 len. 20]: I do n't know what I shall do for joy when I see their kind faces once again ! '
Parsing [sent. 5163 len. 16]: In a short time Oliver was sufficiently recovered to undergo the fatigue of this expedition .
Parsing [sent. 5164 len. 21]: One morning he and Mr. Losberne set out , accordingly , in a little carriage which belonged to Mrs. Maylie .
Parsing [sent. 5165 len. 18]: When they came to Chertsey Bridge , Oliver turned very pale , and uttered a loud exclamation .

Parsing [sent. 5167 len. 12]: cried the doctor , as usual , all in a bustle .

Parsing [sent. 5180 len. 5]: let me out ! '
Parsing [sent. 5181 len. 43]: But , before the coachman could dismount from his box , he had tumbled out of the coach , by some means or other ; and , running down to the deserted tenement , began kicking at the door like a madman .
Parsing [sent. 5182 len. 4]: ` Halloa ? '
Parsing [sent. 5183 len. 33]: said a little ugly hump-backed man : opening the door so suddenly , that the doctor , from the very impetus of his last kick , nearly fell forward into the passage .

Parsing [sent. 5195 len. 23]: Before he could shut the door , however , the doctor had passed into the parlour , without a word of parley .
Parsing [sent. 5196 len. 34]: He looked anxiously round ; not an article of furniture ; not a vestige of anything , animate or inanimate ; not even the position of the cupboards ; answered Oliver 's description !

Parsing [sent. 5200 len. 5]: Which is it ? '

Parsing [sent. 5202 len. 5]: said the irritable doctor .
Parsing [sent. 5203 len. 9]: ` What do you want , then ? '
Parsing [sent. 5204 len. 4]: demanded the hunchback .
Parsing [sent. 5205 len. 14]: ` Will you take yourself off , before I do you a mischief ?
Parsing [sent. 5206 len. 4]: Curse you ! '
Parsing [sent. 5207 len. 37]: ` As soon as I think proper , ' said Mr. Losberne , looking into the other parlour ; which , like the first , bore no resemblance whatever to Oliver 's account of it . '
Parsing [sent. 5208 len. 13]: I shall find you out , some day , my friend . '
Parsing [sent. 5209 len. 5]: ` Will you ? '
Parsing [sent. 5210 len. 5]: sneered the ill-favoured cripple .
Parsing [sent. 5211 len. 11]: ` If you ever want me , I 'm here .
Parsing [sent. 5212 len. 20]: I have n't lived here mad and all alone , for five-and-twenty years , to be scared by you .
Parsing [sent. 5213 len. 13]: You shall pay for this ; you shall pay for this . '
Parsing [sent. 5214 len. 25]: And so saying , the mis-shapen little demon set up a yell , and danced upon the ground , as if wild with rage .
Parsing [sent. 5215 len. 22]: ` Stupid enough , this , ' muttered the doctor to himself ; ` the boy must have made a mistake .
Parsing [sent. 5216 len. 2]: Here !
Parsing [sent. 5217 len. 13]: Put that in your pocket , and shut yourself up again . '
Parsing [sent. 5218 len. 18]: With these words he flung the hunchback a piece of money , and returned to the carriage .
Parsing [sent. 5219 len. 73]: The man followed to the chariot door , uttering the wildest imprecations and curses all the way ; but as Mr. Losberne turned to speak to the driver , he looked into the carriage , and eyed Oliver for an instant with a glance so sharp and fierce and at the same time so furious and vindictive , that , waking or sleeping , he could not forget it for months afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 5220 len. 56]: He continued to utter the most fearful imprecations , until the driver had resumed his seat ; and when they were once more on their way , they could see him some distance behind : beating his feet upon the ground , and tearing his hair , in transports of real or pretended rage . '
Parsing [sent. 5221 len. 6]: I am an ass ! '
Parsing [sent. 5222 len. 9]: said the doctor , after a long silence .
Parsing [sent. 5223 len. 10]: ` Did you know that before , Oliver ? '
Parsing [sent. 5224 len. 6]: ` No , sir . '
Parsing [sent. 5225 len. 10]: ` Then do n't forget it another time . '
Parsing [sent. 5226 len. 18]: ` An ass , ' said the doctor again , after a further silence of some minutes .
Parsing [sent. 5227 len. 26]: ` Even if it had been the right place , and the right fellows had been there , what could I have done , single-handed ?
Parsing [sent. 5228 len. 40]: And if I had had assistance , I see no good that I should have done , except leading to my own exposure , and an unavoidable statement of the manner in which I have hushed up this business .
Parsing [sent. 5229 len. 9]: That would have served me right , though .
Parsing [sent. 5230 len. 16]: I am always involving myself in some scrape or other , by acting on impulse .
Parsing [sent. 5231 len. 8]: It might have done me good . '
Parsing [sent. 5232 len. 63]: Now , the fact was that the excellent doctor had never acted upon anything but impulse all through his life , and if was no bad compliment to the nature of the impulses which governed him , that so far from being involved in any peculiar troubles or misfortunes , he had the warmest respect and esteem of all who knew him .
Parsing [sent. 5233 len. 47]: If the truth must be told , he was a little out of temper , for a minute or two , at being disappointed in procuring corroborative evidence of Oliver 's story on the very first occasion on which he had a chance of obtaining any .
Parsing [sent. 5234 len. 59]: He soon came round again , however ; and finding that Oliver 's replies to his questions , were still as straightforward and consistent , and still delivered with as much apparent sincerity and truth , as they had ever been , he made up his mind to attach full credence to them , from that time forth .
Parsing [sent. 5235 len. 22]: As Oliver knew the name of the street in which Mr. Brownlow resided , they were enabled to drive straight thither .
Parsing [sent. 5236 len. 21]: When the coach turned into it , his heart beat so violently , that he could scarcely draw his breath .
Parsing [sent. 5237 len. 12]: ` Now , my boy , which house is it ? '
Parsing [sent. 5238 len. 4]: inquired Mr. Losberne .
Parsing [sent. 5239 len. 3]: ` That !
Parsing [sent. 5240 len. 3]: That ! '
Parsing [sent. 5241 len. 10]: replied Oliver , pointing eagerly out of the window .
Parsing [sent. 5242 len. 5]: ` The white house .
Parsing [sent. 5243 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5244 len. 3]: make haste !
Parsing [sent. 5245 len. 4]: Pray make haste !
Parsing [sent. 5246 len. 15]: I feel as if I should die : it makes me tremble so . '
Parsing [sent. 5247 len. 6]: ` Come , come ! '
Parsing [sent. 5248 len. 11]: said the good doctor , patting him on the shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 5249 len. 20]: ` You will see them directly , and they will be overjoyed to find you safe and well . '
Parsing [sent. 5250 len. 3]: ` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5251 len. 5]: I hope so ! '
Parsing [sent. 5252 len. 3]: cried Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5253 len. 17]: ` They were so good to me ; so very , very good to me . '
Parsing [sent. 5254 len. 5]: The coach rolled on .
Parsing [sent. 5255 len. 3]: It stopped .
Parsing [sent. 5256 len. 12]: No ; that was the wrong house ; the next door .
Parsing [sent. 5257 len. 11]: It went on a few paces , and stopped again .
Parsing [sent. 5258 len. 17]: Oliver looked up at the windows , with tears of happy expectation coursing down his face .
Parsing [sent. 5259 len. 2]: Alas !
Parsing [sent. 5260 len. 15]: the white house was empty , and there was a bill in the window .
Parsing [sent. 5261 len. 5]: ` To Let . '
Parsing [sent. 5262 len. 19]: ` Knock at the next door , ' cried Mr. Losberne , taking Oliver 's arm in his .
Parsing [sent. 5263 len. 22]: ` What has become of Mr. Brownlow , who used to live in the adjoining house , do you know ? '
Parsing [sent. 5264 len. 12]: The servant did not know ; but would go and inquire .
Parsing [sent. 5265 len. 27]: She presently returned , and said , that Mr. Brownlow had sold off his goods , and gone to the West Indies , six weeks before .
Parsing [sent. 5266 len. 10]: Oliver clasped his hands , and sank feebly backward .
Parsing [sent. 5267 len. 8]: ` Has his housekeeper gone too ? '
Parsing [sent. 5268 len. 10]: inquired Mr. Losberne , after a moment 's pause .
Parsing [sent. 5269 len. 10]: ` Yes , sir ' ; replied the servant .
Parsing [sent. 5270 len. 24]: ` The old gentleman , the housekeeper , and a gentleman who was a friend of Mr. Brownlow 's , all went together .
Parsing [sent. 5271 len. 35]: ` Then turn towards home again , ' said Mr. Losberne to the driver ; ` and do n't stop to bait the horses , till you get out of this confounded London ! '
Parsing [sent. 5272 len. 8]: ` The book-stall keeper , sir ? '
Parsing [sent. 5273 len. 4]: said Oliver . '
Parsing [sent. 5274 len. 6]: I know the way there .
Parsing [sent. 5275 len. 7]: See him , pray , sir !
Parsing [sent. 5276 len. 5]: Do see him ! '
Parsing [sent. 5277 len. 18]: ` My poor boy , this is disappointment enough for one day , ' said the doctor .
Parsing [sent. 5278 len. 8]: ` Quite enough for both of us .
Parsing [sent. 5279 len. 30]: If we go to the book-stall keeper 's , we shall certainly find that he is dead , or has set his house on fire , or run away .
Parsing [sent. 5280 len. 7]: No ; home again straight ! '
Parsing [sent. 5281 len. 13]: And in obedience to the doctor 's impulse , home they went .
Parsing [sent. 5282 len. 82]: This bitter disappointment caused Oliver much sorrow and grief , even in the midst of his happiness ; for he had pleased himself , many times during his illness , with thinking of all that Mr. Brownlow and Mrs. Bedwin would say to him : and what delight it would be to tell them how many long days and nights he had passed in reflecting on what they had done for him , and in bewailing his cruel separation from them .
Parsing [sent. 5283 len. 83]: The hope of eventually clearing himself with them , too , and explaining how he had been forced away , had buoyed him up , and sustained him , under many of his recent trials ; and now , the idea that they should have gone so far , and carried with them the belief that the was an impostor and a robber -- a belief which might remain uncontradicted to his dying day -- was almost more than he could bear .
Parsing [sent. 5284 len. 15]: The circumstance occasioned no alteration , however , in the behaviour of his benefactors .
Parsing [sent. 5285 len. 42]: After another fortnight , when the fine warm weather had fairly begun , and every tree and flower was putting forth its young leaves and rich blossoms , they made preparations for quitting the house at Chertsey , for some months .
Parsing [sent. 5286 len. 47]: Sending the plate , which had so excited Fagin 's cupidity , to the banker 's ; and leaving Giles and another servant in care of the house , they departed to a cottage at some distance in the country , and took Oliver with them .
Parsing [sent. 5287 len. 39]: Who can describe the pleasure and delight , the peace of mind and soft tranquillity , the sickly boy felt in the balmy air , and among the green hills and rich woods , of an inland village !
Parsing [sent. 5288 len. 34]: Who can tell how scenes of peace and quietude sink into the minds of pain-worn dwellers in close and noisy places , and carry their own freshness , deep into their jaded hearts !
Parsing [sent. 5289 len. 109]: Men who have lived in crowded , pent-up streets , through lives of toil , and who have never wished for change ; men , to whom custom has indeed been second nature , and who have come almost to love each brick and stone that formed the narrow boundaries of their daily walks ; even they , with the hand of death upon them , have been known to yearn at last for one short glimpse of Nature 's face ; and , carried far from the scenes of their old pains and pleasures , have seemed to pass at once into a new state of being .
Parsing [sent. 5290 len. 87]: Crawling forth , from day to day , to some green sunny spot , they have had such memories wakened up within them by the sight of the sky , and hill and plain , and glistening water , that a foretaste of heaven itself has soothed their quick decline , and they have sunk into their tombs , as peacefully as the sun whose setting they watched from their lonely chamber window but a few hours before , faded from their dim and feeble sight !
Parsing [sent. 5291 len. 22]: The memories which peaceful country scenes call up , are not of this world , nor of its thoughts and hopes .
Parsing [sent. 5292 len. 88]: Their gentle influence may teach us how to weave fresh garlands for the graves of those we loved : may purify our thoughts , and bear down before it old enmity and hatred ; but beneath all this , there lingers , in the least reflective mind , a vague and half-formed consciousness of having held such feelings long before , in some remote and distant time , which calls up solemn thoughts of distant times to come , and bends down pride and worldliness beneath it .
Parsing [sent. 5293 len. 10]: It was a lovely spot to which they repaired .
Parsing [sent. 5294 len. 29]: Oliver , whose days had been spent among squalid crowds , and in the midst of noise and brawling , seemed to enter on a new existence there .
Parsing [sent. 5295 len. 30]: The rose and honeysuckle clung to the cottage walls ; the ivy crept round the trunks of the trees ; and the garden-flowers perfumed the air with delicious odours .
Parsing [sent. 5296 len. 41]: Hard by , was a little churchyard ; not crowded with tall unsightly gravestones , but full of humble mounds , covered with fresh turf and moss : beneath which , the old people of the village lay at rest .
Parsing [sent. 5297 len. 65]: Oliver often wandered here ; and , thinking of the wretched grave in which his mother lay , would sometimes sit him down and sob unseen ; but , when he raised his eyes to the deep sky overhead , he would cease to think of her as lying in the ground , and would weep for her , sadly , but without pain .
Parsing [sent. 5298 len. 6]: It was a happy time .
Parsing [sent. 5299 len. 37]: The days were peaceful and serene ; the nights brought with them neither fear nor care ; no languishing in a wretched prison , or associating with wretched men ; nothing but pleasant and happy thoughts .
Parsing [sent. 5300 len. 49]: Every morning he went to a white-headed old gentleman , who lived near the little church : who taught him to read better , and to write : and who spoke so kindly , and took such pains , that Oliver could never try enough to please him .
Parsing [sent. 5301 len. 53]: Then , he would walk with Mrs. Maylie and Rose , and hear them talk of books ; or perhaps sit near them , in some shady place , and listen whilst the young lady read : which he could have done , until it grew too dark to see the letters .
Parsing [sent. 5302 len. 96]: Then , he had his own lesson for the next day to prepare ; and at this , he would work hard , in a little room which looked into the garden , till evening came slowly on , when the ladies would walk out again , and he with them : listening with such pleasure to all they said : and so happy if they wanted a flower that he could climb to reach , or had forgotten anything he could run to fetch : that he could never be quick enought about it .
Parsing [sent. 5303 len. 48]: When it became quite dark , and they returned home , the young lady would sit down to the piano , and play some pleasant air , or sing , in a low and gentle voice , some old song which it pleased her aunt to hear .
Parsing [sent. 5304 len. 33]: There would be no candles lighted at such times as these ; and Oliver would sit by one of the windows , listening to the sweet music , in a perfect rapture .
Parsing [sent. 5305 len. 24]: And when Sunday came , how differently the day was spent , from any way in which he had ever spent it yet !
Parsing [sent. 5306 len. 16]: and how happily too ; like all the other days in that most happy time !
Parsing [sent. 5307 len. 44]: There was the little church , in the morning , with the green leaves fluttering at the windows : the birds singing without : and the sweet-smelling air stealing in at the low porch , and filling the homely building with its fragrance .
Parsing [sent. 5308 len. 66]: The poor people were so neat and clean , and knelt so reverently in prayer , that it seemed a pleasure , not a tedious duty , their assembling there together ; and though the singing might be rude , it was real , and sounded more musical -LRB- to Oliver 's ears at least -RRB- than any he had ever heard in church before .
Parsing [sent. 5309 len. 67]: Then , there were the walks as usual , and many calls at the clean houses of the labouring men ; and at night , Oliver read a chapter or two from the Bible , which he had been studying all the week , and in the performance of which duty he felt more proud and pleased , than if he had been the clergyman himself .
Parsing [sent. 5310 len. 63]: In the morning , Oliver would be a-foot by six o'clock , roaming the fields , and plundering the hedges , far and wide , for nosegays of wild flowers , with which he would return laden , home ; and which it took great care and consideration to arrange , to the best advantage , for the embellishment of the breakfast-table .
Parsing [sent. 5311 len. 43]: There was fresh groundsel , too , for Miss Maylie 's birds , with which Oliver , who had been studying the subject under the able tuition of the village clerk , would decorate the cages , in the most approved taste .
Parsing [sent. 5312 len. 115]: When the birds were made all spruce and smart for the day , there was usually some little commission of charity to execute in the village ; or , failing that , there was rare cricket-playing , sometimes , on the green ; or , failing that , there was always something to do in the garden , or about the plants , to which Oliver -LRB- who had studied this science also , under the same master , who was a gardener by trade , -RRB- applied himself with hearty good-will , until Miss Rose made her appearance : when there were a thousand commendations to be bestowed on all he had done .
Parsing [sent. 5313 len. 38]: So three months glided away ; three months which , in the life of the most blessed and favoured of mortals , might have been unmingled happiness , and which , in Oliver 's were true felicity .
Parsing [sent. 5314 len. 76]: With the purest and most amiable generousity on one side ; and the truest , warmest , soul-felt gratitude on the other ; it is no wonder that , by the end of that short time , Oliver Twist had become completely domesticated with the old lady and her niece , and that the fervent attachment of his young and sensitive heart , was repaid by their pride in , and attachment to , himself .
Parsing [sent. 5315 len. 24]: CHAPTER XXXIII WHEREIN THE HAPPINESS OF OLIVER AND HIS FRIENDS , EXPERIENCES A SUDDEN CHECK Spring flew swiftly by , and summer came .
Parsing [sent. 5316 len. 21]: If the village had been beautiful at first it was now in the full glow and luxuriance of its richness .
Parsing [sent. 5317 len. 69]: The great trees , which had looked shrunken and bare in the earlier months , had now burst into strong life and health ; and stretching forth their green arms over the thirsty ground , converted open and naked spots into choice nooks , where was a deep and pleasant shade from which to look upon the wide prospect , steeped in sunshine , which lay stretched beyond .
Parsing [sent. 5318 len. 17]: The earth had donned her mantle of brightest green ; and shed her richest perfumes abroad .
Parsing [sent. 5319 len. 17]: It was the prime and vigour of the year ; all things were glad and flourishing .
Parsing [sent. 5320 len. 23]: Still , the same quiet life went on at the little cottage , and the same cheerful serenity prevailed among its inmates .
Parsing [sent. 5321 len. 26]: Oliver had long since grown stout and healthy ; but health or sickness made no difference in his warm feelings of a great many people .
Parsing [sent. 5322 len. 42]: He was still the same gentle , attached , affectionate creature that he had been when pain and suffering had wasted his strength , and when he was dependent for every slight attention , and comfort on those who tended him .
Parsing [sent. 5323 len. 45]: One beautiful night , when they had taken a longer walk than was customary with them : for the day had been unusually warm , and there was a brilliant moon , and a light wind had sprung up , which was unusually refreshing .
Parsing [sent. 5324 len. 28]: Rose had been in high spirits , too , and they had walked on , in merry conversation , until they had far exceeded their ordinary bounds .
Parsing [sent. 5325 len. 11]: Mrs. Maylie being fatigued , they returned more slowly home .
Parsing [sent. 5326 len. 18]: The young lady merely throwing off her simple bonnet , sat down to the piano as usual .
Parsing [sent. 5327 len. 37]: After running abstractedly over the keys for a few minutes , she fell into a low and very solemn air ; and as she played it , they heard a sound as if she were weeping .
Parsing [sent. 5328 len. 7]: ` Rose , my dear ! '
Parsing [sent. 5329 len. 5]: said the elder lady .
Parsing [sent. 5330 len. 23]: Rose made no reply , but played a little quicker , as though the words had roused her from some painful thoughts .
Parsing [sent. 5331 len. 7]: ` Rose , my love ! '
Parsing [sent. 5332 len. 12]: cried Mrs. Maylie , rising hastily , and bending over her .
Parsing [sent. 5333 len. 5]: ` What is this ?
Parsing [sent. 5334 len. 3]: In tears !
Parsing [sent. 5335 len. 9]: My dear child , what distresses you ? '
Parsing [sent. 5336 len. 14]: ` Nothing , aunt ; nothing , ' replied the young lady . '
Parsing [sent. 5337 len. 27]: I do n't know what it is ; I ca n't describe it ; but I feel -- ' ` Not ill , my love ? '
Parsing [sent. 5338 len. 4]: interposed Mrs. Maylie .
Parsing [sent. 5339 len. 5]: ` No , no !
Parsing [sent. 5340 len. 6]: Oh , not ill ! '
Parsing [sent. 5341 len. 25]: replied Rose : shuddering as though some deadly chillness were passing over her , while she spoke ; ' I shall be better presently .
Parsing [sent. 5342 len. 7]: Close the window , pray ! '
Parsing [sent. 5343 len. 8]: Oliver hastened to comply with her request .
Parsing [sent. 5344 len. 28]: The young lady , making an effort to recover her cheerfulness , strove to play some livelier tune ; but her fingers dropped powerless over the keys .
Parsing [sent. 5345 len. 27]: Covering her face with her hands , she sank upon a sofa , and gave vent to the tears which she was now unable to repress .
Parsing [sent. 5346 len. 5]: ` My child ! '
Parsing [sent. 5347 len. 21]: said the elderly lady , folding her arms about her , ' I never saw you so before . ' '
Parsing [sent. 5348 len. 30]: I would not alarm you if I could avoid it , ' rejoined Rose ; ` but indeed I have tried very hard , and can not help this .
Parsing [sent. 5349 len. 9]: I fear I AM ill , aunt . '
Parsing [sent. 5350 len. 40]: She was , indeed ; for , when candles were brought , they saw that in the very short time which had elapsed since their return home , the hue of her countenance had changed to a marble whiteness .
Parsing [sent. 5351 len. 33]: Its expression had lost nothing of its beauty ; but it was changed ; and there was an anxious haggard look about the gentle face , which it had never worn before .
Parsing [sent. 5352 len. 23]: Another minute , and it was suffused with a crimson flush : and a heavy wildness came over the soft blue eye .
Parsing [sent. 5353 len. 21]: Again this disappeared , like the shadow thrown by a passing cloud ; and she was once more deadly pale .
Parsing [sent. 5354 len. 94]: Oliver , who watched the old lady anxiously , observed that she was alarmed by these appearances ; and so in truth , was he ; but seeing that she affected to make light of them , he endeavoured to do the same , and they so far succeeded , that when Rose was persuaded by her aunt to retire for the night , she was in better spirits ; and appeared even in better health : assuring them that she felt certain she should rise in the morning , quite well . '
Parsing [sent. 5355 len. 19]: I hope , ' said Oliver , when Mrs. Maylie returned , ` that nothing is the matter ?
Parsing [sent. 5356 len. 38]: She do n't look well to-night , but -- ' The old lady motioned to him not to speak ; and sitting herself down in a dark corner of the room , remained silent for some time .
Parsing [sent. 5357 len. 18]: At length , she said , in a trembling voice : ' I hope not , Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5358 len. 16]: I have been very happy with her for some years : too happy , perhaps .
Parsing [sent. 5359 len. 21]: It may be time that I should meet with some misfortune ; but I hope it is not this . '
Parsing [sent. 5360 len. 4]: ` What ? '
Parsing [sent. 5361 len. 3]: inquired Oliver .

Parsing [sent. 5363 len. 3]: ` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5364 len. 4]: God forbid ! '
Parsing [sent. 5365 len. 5]: exclaimed Oliver , hastily .
Parsing [sent. 5366 len. 9]: ` Amen to that , my child ! '
Parsing [sent. 5367 len. 9]: said the old lady , wringing her hands .
Parsing [sent. 5368 len. 12]: ` Surely there is no danger of anything so dreadful ? '
Parsing [sent. 5369 len. 3]: said Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5370 len. 11]: ` Two hours ago , she was quite well . '
Parsing [sent. 5371 len. 22]: ` She is very ill now , ' rejoined Mrs. Maylies ; ` and will be worse , I am sure .
Parsing [sent. 5372 len. 6]: My dear , dear Rose !
Parsing [sent. 5373 len. 10]: Oh , what shall I do without her ! '
Parsing [sent. 5374 len. 46]: She gave way to such great grief , that Oliver , suppressing his own emotion , ventured to remonstrate with her ; and to beg , earnestly , that , for the sake of the dear young lady herself , she would be more calm .
Parsing [sent. 5375 len. 27]: ` And consider , ma'am , ' said Oliver , as the tears forced themselves into his eyes , despite of his efforts to the contrary .
Parsing [sent. 5376 len. 3]: ` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5377 len. 20]: consider how young and good she is , and what pleasure and comfort she gives to all about her .
Parsing [sent. 5378 len. 42]: I am sure -- certain -- quite certain -- that , for your sake , who are so good yourself ; and for her own ; and for the sake of all she makes so happy ; she will not die .
Parsing [sent. 5379 len. 10]: Heaven will never let her die so young . '
Parsing [sent. 5380 len. 4]: ` Hush ! '
Parsing [sent. 5381 len. 12]: said Mrs. Maylie , laying her hand on Oliver 's head .
Parsing [sent. 5382 len. 10]: ` You think like a child , poor boy .
Parsing [sent. 5383 len. 9]: But you teach me my duty , notwithstanding .
Parsing [sent. 5384 len. 44]: I had forgotten it for a moment , Oliver , but I hope I may be pardoned , for I am old , and have seen enough of illness and death to know the agony of separation from the objects of our love .
Parsing [sent. 5385 len. 68]: I have seen enough , too , to know that it is not always the youngest and best who are spared to those that love them ; but this should give us comfort in our sorrow ; for Heaven is just ; and such things teach us , impressively , that there is a brighter world than this ; and that the passage to it is speedy .
Parsing [sent. 5386 len. 6]: God 's will be done !
Parsing [sent. 5387 len. 11]: I love her ; and He know how well ! '
Parsing [sent. 5388 len. 36]: Oliver was surprised to see that as Mrs. Maylie said these words , she checked her lamentations as though by one effort ; and drawing herself up as she spoke , became composed and firm .
Parsing [sent. 5389 len. 54]: He was still more astonished to find that this firmness lasted ; and that , under all the care and watching which ensued , Mrs. Maylie was every ready and collected : performing all the duties which had devolved upon her , steadily , and , to all external appearances , even cheerfully .
Parsing [sent. 5390 len. 20]: But he was young , and did not know what strong minds are capable of , under trying circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 5391 len. 12]: How should he , when their possessors so seldom know themselves ?
Parsing [sent. 5392 len. 5]: An anxious night ensued .
Parsing [sent. 5393 len. 14]: When morning came , Mrs. Maylie 's predictions were but too well verified .
Parsing [sent. 5394 len. 13]: Rose was in the first stage of a high and dangerous fever .
Parsing [sent. 5395 len. 52]: ` We must be active , Oliver , and not give way to useless grief , ' said Mrs. Maylie , laying her finger on her lip , as she looked steadily into his face ; ` this letter must be sent , with all possible expedition , to Mr. Losberne .

Parsing [sent. 5397 len. 26]: The people at the inn will undertake to do this : and I can trust to you to see it done , I know . '
Parsing [sent. 5398 len. 16]: Oliver could make no reply , but looked his anxiety to be gone at once .
Parsing [sent. 5399 len. 37]: ` Here is another letter , ' said Mrs. Maylie , pausing to reflect ; ` but whether to send it now , or wait until I see how Rose goes on , I scarcely know .
Parsing [sent. 5400 len. 13]: I would not forward it , unless I feared the worst . '
Parsing [sent. 5401 len. 11]: ` Is it for Chertsey , too , ma'am ? '

Parsing [sent. 5409 len. 27]: With these words , she gave Oliver her purse , and he started off , without more delay , at the greatest speed he could muster .
Parsing [sent. 5410 len. 89]: Swiftly he ran across the fields , and down the little lanes which sometimes divided them : now almost hidden by the high corn on either side , and now emerging on an open field , where the mowers and haymakers were busy at their work : nor did he stop once , save now and then , for a few seconds , to recover breath , until he came , in a great heat , and covered with dust , on the little market-place of the market-town .
Parsing [sent. 5411 len. 11]: Here he paused , and looked about for the inn .
Parsing [sent. 5412 len. 46]: There were a white bank , and a red brewery , and a yellow town-hall ; and in one corner there was a large house , with all the wood about it painted green : before which was the sign of ` The George . '
Parsing [sent. 5413 len. 13]: To this he hastened , as soon as it caught his eye .
Parsing [sent. 5414 len. 83]: He spoke to a postboy who was dozing under the gateway ; and who , after hearing what he wanted , referred him to the ostler ; who after hearing all he had to say again , referred him to the landlord ; who was a tall gentleman in a blue neckcloth , a white hat , drab breeches , and boots with tops to match , leaning against a pump by the stable-door , picking his teeth with a silver toothpick .
Parsing [sent. 5415 len. 54]: This gentleman walked with much deliberation into the bar to make out the bill : which took a long time making out : and after it was ready , and paid , a horse had to be saddled , and a man to be dressed , which took up ten good minutes more .
Parsing [sent. 5416 len. 39]: Meanwhile Oliver was in such a desperate state of impatience and anxiety , that he felt as if he could have jumped upon the horse himself , and galloped away , full tear , to the next stage .
Parsing [sent. 5417 len. 62]: At length , all was ready ; and the little parcel having been handed up , with many injunctions and entreaties for its speedy delivery , the man set spurs to his horse , and rattling over the uneven paving of the market-place , was out of the town , and galloping along the turnpike-road , in a couple of minutes .
Parsing [sent. 5418 len. 33]: As it was something to feel certain that assistance was sent for , and that no time had been lost , Oliver hurried up the inn-yard , with a somewhat lighter heart .
Parsing [sent. 5419 len. 32]: He was turning out of the gateway when he accidently stumbled against a tall man wrapped in a cloak , who was at that moment coming out of the inn door .
Parsing [sent. 5420 len. 4]: ` Hah ! '
Parsing [sent. 5421 len. 14]: cried the man , fixing his eyes on Oliver , and suddenly recoiling .
Parsing [sent. 5422 len. 9]: ` What the devil 's this ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 5423 len. 31]: I beg your pardon , sir , ' said Oliver ; ' I was in a great hurry to get home , and did n't see you were coming . '
Parsing [sent. 5424 len. 4]: ` Death ! '
Parsing [sent. 5425 len. 16]: muttered the man to himself , glaring at the boy with his large dark eyes .
Parsing [sent. 5426 len. 7]: ` Who would have thought it !
Parsing [sent. 5427 len. 5]: Grind him to ashes !
Parsing [sent. 5428 len. 17]: He 'd start up from a stone coffin , to come in my way ! ' '
Parsing [sent. 5429 len. 18]: I am sorry , ' stammered Oliver , confused by the strange man 's wild look . '
Parsing [sent. 5430 len. 9]: I hope I have not hurt you ! '
Parsing [sent. 5431 len. 5]: ` Rot you ! '
Parsing [sent. 5432 len. 38]: murmured the man , in a horrible passion ; between his clenched teeth ; ` if I had only had the courage to say the word , I might have been free of you in a night .

Parsing [sent. 5434 len. 7]: What are you doing here ? '
Parsing [sent. 5435 len. 13]: The man shook his fist , as he uttered these words incoherently .
Parsing [sent. 5436 len. 32]: He advanced towards Oliver , as if with the intention of aiming a blow at him , but fell violently on the ground : writhing and foaming , in a fit .
Parsing [sent. 5437 len. 32]: Oliver gazed , for a moment , at the struggles of the madman -LRB- for such he supposed him to be -RRB- ; and then darted into the house for help .
Parsing [sent. 5438 len. 54]: Having seen him safely carried into the hotel , he turned his face homewards , running as fast as he could , to make up for lost time : and recalling with a great deal of astonishment and some fear , the extraordinary behaviour of the person from whom he had just parted .
Parsing [sent. 5439 len. 39]: The circumstance did not dwell in his recollection long , however : for when he reached the cottage , there was enough to occupy his mind , and to drive all considerations of self completely from his memory .
Parsing [sent. 5440 len. 13]: Rose Maylie had rapidly grown worse ; before mid-night she was delirious .
Parsing [sent. 5441 len. 44]: A medical practitioner , who resided on the spot , was in constant attendance upon her ; and after first seeing the patient , he had taken Mrs. Maylie aside , and pronounced her disorder to be one of a most alarming nature .
Parsing [sent. 5442 len. 23]: ` In fact , ' he said , ` it would be little short of a miracle , if she recovered . '
Parsing [sent. 5443 len. 33]: How often did Oliver start from his bed that night , and stealing out , with noiseless footstep , to the staircase , listen for the slightest sound from the sick chamber !
Parsing [sent. 5444 len. 42]: How often did a tremble shake his frame , and cold drops of terror start upon his brow , when a sudden trampling of feet caused him to fear that something too dreadful to think of , had even then occurred !
Parsing [sent. 5445 len. 52]: And what had been the fervency of all the prayers he had ever muttered , compared with those he poured forth , now , in the agony and passion of his supplication for the life and health of the gentle creature , who was tottering on the deep grave 's verge !
Parsing [sent. 5446 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5447 len. 28]: the suspense , the fearful , acute suspense , of standing idly by while the life of one we dearly love , is trembling in the balance !
Parsing [sent. 5448 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5449 len. 100]: the racking thoughts that crowd upon the mind , and make the heart beat violently , and the breath come thick , by the force of the images they conjure up before it ; the DESPERATE ANXIETY TO BE DOING SOMETHING to relieve the pain , or lessen the danger , which we have no power to alleviate ; the sinking of soul and spirit , which the sad remembrance of our helplessness produces ; what tortures can equal these ; what reflections or endeavours can , in the full tide and fever of the time , allay them !
Parsing [sent. 5450 len. 12]: Morning came ; and the little cottage was lonely and still .
Parsing [sent. 5451 len. 25]: People spoke in whispers ; anxious faces appeared at the gate , from time to time ; women and children went away in tears .
Parsing [sent. 5452 len. 49]: All the livelong day , and for hours after it had grown dark , Oliver paced softly up and down the garden , raising his eyes every instant to the sick chamber , and shuddering to see the darkened window , looking as if death lay stretched inside .
Parsing [sent. 5453 len. 8]: Late that night , Mr. Losberne arrived .
Parsing [sent. 5454 len. 33]: ` It is hard , ' said the good doctor , turning away as he spoke ; ` so young ; so much beloved ; but there is very little hope . '
Parsing [sent. 5455 len. 3]: Another morning .
Parsing [sent. 5456 len. 58]: The sun shone brightly ; as brightly as if it looked upon no misery or care ; and , with every leaf and flower in full bloom about her ; with life , and health , and sounds and sights of joy , surrounding her on every side : the fair young creature lay , wasting fast .
Parsing [sent. 5457 len. 27]: Oliver crept away to the old churchyard , and sitting down on one of the green mounds , wept and prayed for her , in silence .
Parsing [sent. 5458 len. 115]: There was such peace and beauty in the scene ; so much of brightness and mirth in the sunny landscape ; such blithesome music in the songs of the summer birds ; such freedom in the rapid flight of the rook , careering overhead ; so much of life and joyousness in all ; that , when the boy raised his aching eyes , and looked about , the thought instinctively occurred to him , that this was not a time for death ; that Rose could surely never die when humbler things were all so glad and gay ; that graves were for cold and cheerless winter : not for sunlight and fragrance .
Parsing [sent. 5459 len. 27]: He almost thought that shrouds were for the old and shrunken ; and that they never wrapped the young and graceful form in their ghastly folds .
Parsing [sent. 5460 len. 13]: A knell from the church bell broke harshly on these youthful thoughts .
Parsing [sent. 5461 len. 2]: Another !
Parsing [sent. 5462 len. 2]: Again !
Parsing [sent. 5463 len. 8]: It was tolling for the funeral service .
Parsing [sent. 5464 len. 19]: A group of humble mourners entered the gate : wearing white favours ; for the corpse was young .
Parsing [sent. 5465 len. 22]: They stood uncovered by a grave ; and there was a mother -- a mother once -- among the weeping train .
Parsing [sent. 5466 len. 12]: But the sun shone brightly , and the birds sang on .
Parsing [sent. 5467 len. 40]: Oliver turned homeward , thinking on the many kindnesses he had received from the young lady , and wishing that the time could come again , that he might never cease showing her how grateful and attached he was .
Parsing [sent. 5468 len. 58]: He had no cause for self-reproach on the score of neglect , or want of thought , for he had been devoted to her service ; and yet a hundred little occasions rose up before him , on which he fancied he might have been more zealous , and more earnest , and wished he had been .
Parsing [sent. 5469 len. 50]: We need be careful how we deal with those about us , when every death carries to some small circle of survivors , thoughts of so much omitted , and so little done -- of so many things forgotten , and so many more which might have been repaired !
Parsing [sent. 5470 len. 28]: There is no remorse so deep as that which is unavailing ; if we would be spared its tortures , let us remember this , in time .
Parsing [sent. 5471 len. 13]: When he reached home Mrs. Maylie was sitting in the little parlour .
Parsing [sent. 5472 len. 33]: Oliver 's heart sand at sight of her ; for she had never left the bedside of her niece ; and he trembled to think what change could have driven her away .
Parsing [sent. 5473 len. 32]: He learnt that she had fallen into a deep sleep , from which she would waken , either to recovery and life , or to bid them farewell , and die .
Parsing [sent. 5474 len. 13]: They sat , listening , and afraid to speak , for hours .
Parsing [sent. 5475 len. 45]: The untasted meal was removed , with looks which showed that their thoughts were elsewhere , they watched the sun as he sank lower and lower , and , at length , cast over sky and earth those brilliant hues which herald his departure .
Parsing [sent. 5476 len. 11]: Their quick ears caught the sound of an approaching footstep .
Parsing [sent. 5477 len. 13]: They both involuntarily darted to the door , as Mr. Losberne entered .
Parsing [sent. 5478 len. 6]: ` What of Rose ? '
Parsing [sent. 5479 len. 5]: cried the old lady .
Parsing [sent. 5480 len. 6]: ` Tell me at once !
Parsing [sent. 5481 len. 9]: I can bear it ; anything but suspense !
Parsing [sent. 5482 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 5483 len. 4]: , tell me !
Parsing [sent. 5484 len. 7]: in the name of Heaven ! '
Parsing [sent. 5485 len. 13]: ` You must compose yourself , ' said the doctor supporting her .
Parsing [sent. 5486 len. 11]: ` Be calm , my dear ma'am , pray . '
Parsing [sent. 5487 len. 10]: ` Let me go , in God 's name !
Parsing [sent. 5488 len. 4]: My dear child !
Parsing [sent. 5489 len. 4]: She is dead !
Parsing [sent. 5490 len. 5]: She is dying ! '
Parsing [sent. 5491 len. 4]: ` No ! '
Parsing [sent. 5492 len. 6]: cried the doctor , passionately .
Parsing [sent. 5493 len. 22]: ` As He is good and merciful , she will live to bless us all , for years to come . '
Parsing [sent. 5494 len. 48]: The lady fell upon her knees , and tried to fold her hands together ; but the energy which had supported her so long , fled up to Heaven with her first thanksgiving ; and she sank into the friendly arms which were extended to receive her .
Parsing [sent. 5495 len. 35]: CHAPTER XXIV CONTAINS SOME INTRODUCTORY PARTICULARS RELATIVE TO A YOUNG GENTLEMAN WHO NOW ARRIVES UPON THE SCENE ; AND A NEW ADVENTURE WHICH HAPPENED TO OLIVER It was almost too much happiness to bear .
Parsing [sent. 5496 len. 21]: Oliver felt stunned and stupefied by the unexpected intelligence ; he could not weep , or speak , or rest .
Parsing [sent. 5497 len. 70]: He had scarcely the power of understanding anything that had passed , until , after a long ramble in the quiet evening air , a burst of tears came to his relief , and he seemed to awaken , all at once , to a full sense of the joyful change that had occurred , and the almost insupportable load of anguish which had been taken from his breast .
Parsing [sent. 5498 len. 32]: The night was fast closing in , when he returned homeward : laden with flowers which he had culled , with peculiar care , for the adornment of the sick chamber .
Parsing [sent. 5499 len. 25]: As he walked briskly along the road , he heard behind him , the noise of some vehicle , approaching at a furious pace .
Parsing [sent. 5500 len. 42]: Looking round , he saw that it was a post-chaise , driven at great speed ; and as the horses were galloping , and the road was narrow , he stood leaning against a gate until it should have passed him .
Parsing [sent. 5501 len. 38]: As it dashed on , Oliver caught a glimpse of a man in a white nitecap , whose face seemed familiar to him , although his view was so brief that he could not identify the person .
Parsing [sent. 5502 len. 40]: In another second or two , the nightcap was thrust out of the chaise-window , and a stentorian voice bellowed to the driver to stop : which he did , as soon as he could pull up his horses .
Parsing [sent. 5503 len. 18]: Then , the nightcap once again appeared : and the same voice called Oliver by his name .
Parsing [sent. 5504 len. 4]: ` Here ! '
Parsing [sent. 5505 len. 4]: cried the voice .
Parsing [sent. 5506 len. 8]: ` Oliver , what 's the news ?
Parsing [sent. 5507 len. 3]: Miss Rose !
Parsing [sent. 5508 len. 4]: Master O-li-ver ! '
Parsing [sent. 5509 len. 8]: ` Is is you , Giles ? '
Parsing [sent. 5510 len. 9]: cried Oliver , running up to the chaise-door .
Parsing [sent. 5511 len. 41]: Giles popped out his nightcap again , preparatory to making some reply , when he was suddenly pulled back by a young gentleman who occupied the other corner of the chaise , and who eagerly demanded what was the news .
Parsing [sent. 5512 len. 6]: ` In a word ! '
Parsing [sent. 5513 len. 10]: cried the gentleman , ` Better or worse ? '
Parsing [sent. 5514 len. 7]: ` Better -- much better ! '
Parsing [sent. 5515 len. 5]: replied Oliver , hastily .
Parsing [sent. 5516 len. 5]: ` Thank Heaven ! '
Parsing [sent. 5517 len. 4]: exclaimed the gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 5518 len. 6]: ` You are sure ? '
Parsing [sent. 5519 len. 9]: ` Quite , sir , ' replied Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5520 len. 25]: ` The change took place only a few hours ago ; and Mr. Losberne says , that all danger is at an end . '
Parsing [sent. 5521 len. 28]: The gentleman said not another word , but , opening the chaise-door , leaped out , and taking Oliver hurriedly by the arm , led him aside .
Parsing [sent. 5522 len. 6]: ` You are quite certain ?
Parsing [sent. 5523 len. 18]: There is no possibility of any mistake on your part , my boy , is there ? '
Parsing [sent. 5524 len. 8]: demanded the gentleman in a tremulous voice .
Parsing [sent. 5525 len. 18]: ` Do not deceive me , by awakening hopes that are not to be fulfilled . ' '
Parsing [sent. 5526 len. 13]: I would not for the world , sir , ' replied Oliver .
Parsing [sent. 5527 len. 7]: ` Indeed you may believe me .
Parsing [sent. 5528 len. 20]: Mr. Losberne 's words were , that she would live to bless us all for many years to come .
Parsing [sent. 5529 len. 7]: I heard him say so . '
Parsing [sent. 5530 len. 37]: The tears stood in Oliver 's eyes as he recalled the scene which was the beginning of so much happiness ; and the gentleman turned his face away , and remained silent , for some minutes .
Parsing [sent. 5531 len. 45]: Oliver thought he heard him sob , more than once ; but he feared to interrupt him by any fresh remark -- for he could well guess what his feelings were -- and so stood apart , feigning to be occupied with his nosegay .
Parsing [sent. 5532 len. 44]: All this time , Mr. Giles , with the white nightcap on , had been sitting on the steps of the chaise , supporting an elbow on each knee , and wiping his eyes with a blue cotton pocket-handkerchief dotted with white spots .
Parsing [sent. 5533 len. 35]: That the honest fellow had not been feigning emotion , was abundently demonstrated by the very red eyes with which he regarded the young gentleman , when he turned round and addressed him . '
Parsing [sent. 5534 len. 22]: I think you had better go on to my mother 's in the chaise , Giles , ' said he . '
Parsing [sent. 5535 len. 19]: I would rather walk slowly on , so as to gain a little time before I see her .
Parsing [sent. 5536 len. 9]: You can say I am coming . ' '
Parsing [sent. 5537 len. 45]: I beg your pardon , Mr. Harry , ' said Giles : giving a final polish to his ruffled countenance with the handkerchief ; ` but if you would leave the postboy to say that , I should be very much obliged to you .
Parsing [sent. 5538 len. 31]: It would n't be proper for the maids to see me in this state , sir ; I should never have any more authority with them if they did . '
Parsing [sent. 5539 len. 18]: ` Well , ' rejoined Harry Maylie , smiling , ` you can do as you like .
Parsing [sent. 5540 len. 20]: Let him go on with the luggage , if you wish it , and do you follow with us .
Parsing [sent. 5541 len. 20]: Only first exchange that nightcap for some more appropriate covering , or we shall be taken for madmen . '
Parsing [sent. 5542 len. 35]: Mr. Giles , reminded of his unbecoming costume , snatched off and pocketed his nightcap ; and substituted a hat , of grave and sober shape , which he took out of the chaise .
Parsing [sent. 5543 len. 21]: This done , the postboy drove off ; Giles , Mr. Maylie , and Oliver , followed at their leisure .
Parsing [sent. 5544 len. 21]: As they walked along , Oliver glanced from time to time with much interest and curiosity at the new comer .
Parsing [sent. 5545 len. 29]: He seemed about five-and-twenty years of age , and was of the middle height ; his countenance was frank and handsome ; and his demeanor easy and prepossessing .
Parsing [sent. 5546 len. 44]: Notwithstanding the difference between youth and age , he bore so strong a likeness to the old lady , that Oliver would have had no great difficulty in imagining their relationship , if he had not already spoken of her as his mother .
Parsing [sent. 5547 len. 15]: Mrs. Maylie was anxiously waiting to receive her son when he reached the cottage .
Parsing [sent. 5548 len. 13]: The meeting did not take place without great emotion on both sides .
Parsing [sent. 5549 len. 4]: ` Mother ! '
Parsing [sent. 5550 len. 15]: whispered the young man ; ` why did you not write before ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 5551 len. 31]: I did , ' replied Mrs. Maylie ; ` but , on reflection , I determined to keep back the letter until I had heard Mr. Losberne 's opinion . '
Parsing [sent. 5552 len. 23]: ` But why , ' said the young man , ` why run the chance of that occurring which so nearly happened ?
Parsing [sent. 5553 len. 27]: If Rose had -- I can not utter that word now -- if this illness had terminated differently , how could you ever have forgiven yourself !
Parsing [sent. 5554 len. 10]: How could I ever have know happiness again ! '
Parsing [sent. 5555 len. 51]: ` If that HAD been the case , Harry , ' said Mrs. Maylie , ' I fear your happiness would have been effectually blighted , and that your arrival here , a day sooner or a day later , would have been of very , very little import . '
Parsing [sent. 5556 len. 13]: ` And who can wonder if it be so , mother ? '

Parsing [sent. 5558 len. 20]: -- It is -- it is -- you know it , mother -- you must know it ! ' '

Parsing [sent. 5560 len. 64]: If I did not feel this , and know , besides , that a changed behaviour in one she loved would break her heart , I should not feel my task so difficult of performance , or have to encounter so many struggles in my own bosom , when I take what seems to me to be the strict line of duty . '
Parsing [sent. 5561 len. 11]: ` This is unkind , mother , ' said Harry .
Parsing [sent. 5562 len. 27]: ` Do you still suppose that I am a boy ignorant of my own mind , and mistaking the impulses of my own soul ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 5563 len. 49]: I think , my dear son , ' returned Mrs. Maylie , laying her hand upon his shoulder , ` that youth has many generous impulses which do not last ; and that among them are some , which , being gratified , become only the more fleeting .
Parsing [sent. 5564 len. 120]: Above all , I think ' said the lady , fixing her eyes on her son 's face , ` that if an enthusiastic , ardent , and ambitious man marry a wife on whose name there is a stain , which , though it originate in no fault of hers , may be visited by cold and sordid people upon her , and upon his children also : and , in exact proportion to his success in the world , be cast in his teeth , and made the subject of sneers against him : he may , no matter how generous and good his nature , one day repent of the connection he formed in early life .
Parsing [sent. 5565 len. 14]: And she may have the pain of knowing that he does so . '
Parsing [sent. 5566 len. 38]: ` Mother , ' said the young man , impatiently , ` he would be a selfish brute , unworthy alike of the name of man and of the woman you describe , who acted thus . '
Parsing [sent. 5567 len. 13]: ` You think so now , Harry , ' replied his mother .
Parsing [sent. 5568 len. 6]: ` And ever will ! '
Parsing [sent. 5569 len. 5]: said the young man .
Parsing [sent. 5570 len. 44]: ` The mental agony I have suffered , during the last two days , wrings from me the avowal to you of a passion which , as you well know , is not one of yesterday , nor one I have lightly formed .
Parsing [sent. 5571 len. 8]: On Rose , sweet , gentle girl !
Parsing [sent. 5572 len. 17]: my heart is set , as firmly as ever heart of man was set on woman .

Parsing [sent. 5574 len. 27]: Mother , think better of this , and of me , and do not disregard the happiness of which you seem to think so little . '
Parsing [sent. 5575 len. 31]: ` Harry , ' said Mrs. Maylie , ` it is because I think so much of warm and sensitive hearts , that I would spare them from being wounded .
Parsing [sent. 5576 len. 19]: But we have said enough , and more than enough , on this matter , just now . '
Parsing [sent. 5577 len. 13]: ` Let it rest with Rose , then , ' interposed Harry .

Parsing [sent. 5580 len. 16]: was the impatient reply ; ` Mother , I have considered , years and years .
Parsing [sent. 5581 len. 14]: I have considered , ever since I have been capable of serious reflection .
Parsing [sent. 5582 len. 34]: My feelings remain unchanged , as they ever will ; and why should I suffer the pain of a delay in giving them vent , which can be productive of no earthly good ?
Parsing [sent. 5583 len. 2]: No !
Parsing [sent. 5584 len. 12]: Before I leave this place , Rose shall hear me . '

Parsing [sent. 5592 len. 25]: What I would say , ' resumed the old lady , stopping her son as he was about to speak , ` is this .
Parsing [sent. 5593 len. 94]: Before you stake your all on this chance ; before you suffer yourself to be carried to the highest point of hope ; reflect for a few moments , my dear child , on Rose 's history , and consider what effect the knowledge of her doubtful birth may have on her decision : devoted as she is to us , with all the intensity of her noble mind , and with that perfect sacrifice of self which , in all matters , great or trifling , has always been her characteristic .
